story:
IMERSE is a recently formed NGO operating in the southern African country of Swaziland. We build the skills of non-mental health professionals to provide basic mental health services. We are raising $15,000 to put on a suicide prevention outreach event, implement four training programs, develop mobile applications to complement these trainings and provide support to other organizations working in Swaziland.


Swaziland is currently suffering from a combination of HIV, gender-based violence and poverty:
  • Swaziland has the highest HIV rate in the world (26% of adults are HIV positive).
  • Two out of three Swazi women have experienced sexual violence or abuse.
  • Swaziland has the second worst performing economy in the world.
These factors are associated with higher levels of mental disorders, yet little is being done.
  • There is one psychiatrist for the country’s 1.2 million people.
  • Swaziland has no Mental Health Policy and no mental health promotion unit within the government.
  • IMERSE is the only organization focused on mental health in Swaziland.
Suicide has become a growing problem in Swaziland. Based on the number of suicides reported in the country’s newspaper, Swaziland has one of the highest suicide rates in the world.


IMERSE is the only organization focused on mental health operating in Swaziland. Our past activities have included:
  •  A comprehensive mental health needs assessment involving 33 key informants.


  •  A training of 98 teachers at the Southern African Nazerene University in basic mental health concepts and self-care techniques.
  •  A public outreach event in Mbabane to commemorate Suicide Prevention Day reaching 112 people.
  •  A series of school presentations around Mbabane to commemorate Teen Suicide Prevention Week.


  • A training of 70 female counselors and volunteers in basic psychosocial support, trauma and abuse, as well as grief and loss.
  • Support in developing a mental health questionnaire for Siphilile, an organization that assists HIV positive perinatal mothers.
For more information on what IMERSE did in 2013, please see our 2013 Annual Report at www.imerse.org/

Planned Projects:
After conducting a comprehensive needs assessment and meeting with volunteers and individuals with mental health issues, we concluded:
  • Stigma against people with mental disorders is high. There is a need to improve basic mental health knowledge among the general public.
  • Mental health issues associated with trauma is widespread.
  • Creative mediums tend to be effective in dealing with mental health issues in Swaziland.
  • Suicide is a growing problem in Swaziland.
  • Many Swazis utilize smartphones (typically Nokia, Android and Windows), and mobile applications can be a useful tool to reach a wide audience.
We have the following activities planned for the upcoming year:
  • A training in basic mental health concepts and self-care for community health workers
  • A trauma and abuse counseling training for community leaders
  • Healing through art workshops for individuals with mental health issues
  • A suicide prevention public outreach event in September 2014
  • Support for Partnering organizations including Peace Corps, Siphilile (an organization supporting HIV-positive mothers) and Swaziland Christian University.
  • The development of 3 mobile applications to complement our programs, including
  1.  A mobile application to support suicide interventions
  2. A mobile application that teaches basic mental health concepts and self-care
  3. A mobile application that enables users to use art to heal

Our Needs:
We are raising $5,000.  This money will be used for:
  • A salaried full-time Program Manager
  • IT Equipment for Mobile App Development
  • Four workshops for 80 community health workers, teachers, and community leaders
  • A public outreach event

We are raising $15,000 to put on a suicide prevention outreach event, implement four training programs, develop mobile applications to complement these trainings and provide support to other organizations working in Swaziland.Swaziland is currently suffering from a combination of HIV, gender-based violence and poverty:Swaziland has the highest HIV rate in the world (26% of adults are HIV positive).Two out of three Swazi women have experienced sexual violence or abuse.Swaziland has the second worst performing economy in the world.These factors are associated with higher levels of mental disorders, yet little is being done.There is one psychiatrist for the country’s 1.2 million people.Swaziland has no Mental Health Policy and no mental health promotion unit within the government.IMERSE is the only organization focused on mental health in Swaziland.Suicide has become a growing problem in Swaziland. Based on the number of suicides reported in the country’s newspaper, Swaziland has one of the highest suicide rates in the world.IMERSE is the only organization focused on mental health operating in Swaziland. Our past activities have included: A comprehensive mental health needs assessment involving 33 key informants. A training of 98 teachers at the Southern African Nazerene University in basic mental health concepts and self-care techniques. A public outreach event in Mbabane to commemorate Suicide Prevention Day reaching 112 people. A series of school presentations around Mbabane to commemorate Teen Suicide Prevention Week.A training of 70 female counselors and volunteers in basic psychosocial support, trauma and abuse, as well as grief and loss.Support in developing a mental health questionnaire for Siphilile, an organization that assists HIV positive perinatal mothers.For more information on what IMERSE did in 2013, please see our 2013 Annual Report at www.imerse.org/Planned Projects:After conducting a comprehensive needs assessment and meeting with volunteers and individuals with mental health issues, we concluded:Stigma against people with mental disorders is high. There is a need to improve basic mental health knowledge among the general public.Mental health issues associated with trauma is widespread.Creative mediums tend to be effective in dealing with mental health issues in Swaziland.Suicide is a growing problem in Swaziland.Many Swazis utilize smartphones (typically Nokia, Android and Windows), and mobile applications can be a useful tool to reach a wide audience.We have the following activities planned for the upcoming year:A training in basic mental health concepts and self-care for community health workersA trauma and abuse counseling training for community leadersHealing through art workshops for individuals with mental health issuesA suicide prevention public outreach event in September 2014Support for Partnering organizations including Peace Corps, Siphilile (an organization supporting HIV-positive mothers) and Swaziland Christian University.The development of 3 mobile applications to complement our programs, including
 A mobile application to support suicide interventions
A mobile application that teaches basic mental health concepts and self-care
A mobile application that enables users to use art to heal

Our Needs:We are raising $5,000.  This money will be used for:
A salaried full-time Program Manager
IT Equipment for Mobile App Development
Four workshops for 80 community health workers, teachers, and community leaders
A public outreach event

story:
UPDATE 8/28:

And at the end of our online campaign, we have all raised enough funds to protect about 75 families or 300 people, that's truly amazing! To each and every individual who went out of their way to donate and to spread the word about this campaign, both myself and the LifeNets Foundation team thank you from the bottom of our hearts. We will continue to raise funds up until our mission date.. let's see just how much of a difference we can make!

(Perks will be rewarded within a week or so, stay tuned!)


UPDATE 8/14:

You guys have been wonderful in all your support and contributions toward our campaign! With only 12 days remaining in our IGG Fundraiser, let's kick it into high-gear and make the final push to raise as much support as we can for families in Malawi. So far, we've raised an equivalent of about 42 nets, which could potentially save 168 lives. That's amazing, but let's not be complacent with that.. we can do MORE! Share this page with your friends/family and let's all work together to fight Malaria. Thank you!!


UPDATE 8/1:

Thank you so much to everybody who has donated and shared this campaign so far! An important update we have is that our CEO has made an executive decision to postpone this trip to November. However, we will keep fundraising for the next 3 weeks! The only difference will be that the funds will be utilized in November instead of August; funders who have chosen perks will still receive them at the end of the campaign. Thank you all for your support and let's keep going strong to make this incredible difference!

-------------

 

Malaria

Every year, roughly 219 million people are infected with Malaria and about 660,000 people die from it, most of them are African children.

 

Malaria is caused by Plasmodium parasites, which enter human bloodstreams through infected Anopheles mosquitoes. As a consequence, these mosquito vectors have played a critical role in the spread of Malaria.

 

Perhaps the most tragic aspect is that, unlike many other diseases, Malaria is both curable and preventable. Yet this very disease is the cause of numerous deaths, sicknesses, miscarriages, and even economic losses. Poor or high-burdened regions, such as Central Africa, are particularly at risk, as they lack both the means and the resources to fight this ongoing pandemic.

Our Mission - Join Us!

LifeNets Foundation is a progressive nonprofit organization fighting Malaria, one small yet incredibly significant step at a time. We truly believe that by tackling the deeper issues of malaria, we hold in our hands the ability to eradicate malaria from Malawi and even all of Africa within our lifetime.

As part of our short-term strategy, we have focused on implementing and distributing the insecticide-treated mosquito net. These nets, which can be set up to cover a small sleeping area for the night, play an astoundingly powerful role in preventing mosquito bites and thus, preventing further spread of Malaria. The nets that we distribute are not simply coated with insecticide, but are safely and effectively woven with the insecticide. This provides more safety for the user, as well as longer usage and increased effectiveness.

However, our mission does not simply end with the distribution of these mosquito nets. We ensure that the communities we visit are properly educated on how to most effectively use these nets, so that they may provide maximum protection and last as long as possible. Furthermore, we conduct several follow-up examinations and distributions.. just to be sure the nets are working well!

We Need Your Help...

After a long year of preparations and plans, we are almost ready to embark on our annual mission to Lilongwe, Malawi. In order to provide as many resources and as much help as we can offer, we are aiming to raise an additional $3,780 USD (an equivalent of 315 nets).

 

Our 2013 trip will happen in late November, but we are fundraising ahead of time in order to have plenty of time to reach our goal to help the people of Malawi!

 

It costs only $12 USD per net, so whether you can contribute $1 or $100, please consider making a donation; every dollar counts in the fight against Malaria.

Thank YOU!

Even if you currently cannot contribute financially, you can still help us make a difference. Please consider sharing this link and campaign to your friends and family. Get the word out and let's beat Malaria!

 

 

 

With the utmost gratitude,

-The LifeNets Foundation.

story:
Running a marathon...am I crazy? 

I have never run a marathon, or even a half marathon, but i have taken up this challenge to run the Brighton Marathon on Sunday 14 April 2013 for a gorgeous little boy who can't run or walk... 

What am I raising funds for? 

I'm raising money for 21 month old Evander to travel from his home in Sydney Australia to The Frazier Rehabilitation Institute in Kentucky (USA) for 3 months of intensive physiotherapy to help him walk. 

 

Who is Evander

Evander was born with a neuroblastoma tumour which has left him with a permanent spinal cord injury. The doctors prognosis is that he will be left paraplegic from the tumour. At 21 months old, Evander can not move his legs and can not stand or walk.

Evander is the son of my good friends Clare + Roger Conroy. Clare + I have been friends for almost 20 years. After studying at University together we went on all sorts of fun travelling adventures around the world.

Above:Me and Clare 

Where do your dollars go?

  • The money raised will be used for Evander and Clare (his mother) to travel to Louisville Kentucky(USA) to participate in 3 months of intensive ‘Activity Based Therapy’ program at the Frazier Rehabilitation Institute. (Frazier Rehab is the lead centre in the Christopher & Dana Reeve Foundation's NeuroRecovery Network.) 

  • Other paraplegic children who have worked with the same team at the Fraizer institute have made amazing progress... even standing and eventually walking.
  • The rehab specialists at Frazier are the world experts in 'Locomotor Training' and have spent years focusing on helping children with spinal cord injury to walk.
  • The Evander Conroy Foundation is trying to raise $30,000 Australian dollars for their 80-day intensive therapy program in the States. I am just helping starting them off, anything you can contribute will help.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Join the facebook page for the Evander Conroy Foundation and watch his progress 
  • Share Evander's story with your friends and family.

Australian Sponsors

Anyone in Australia up for sponsoring me please feel free to make a donation directly to the Evander Conroy Foundation. You can then write me a comment here on this site (unfortuantely you'll have to keep the private box ticked) It all goes to the same great cause. Thanks  
http://www.evanderconroyfoundation.org.au/ 

 My Progress 

Since Dec 2012 I've been following a Beginner's Marathon Schedule which so far has taken me from a starting point of 5km through to my first half marathon. Each Sunday the distance i've run has steadily increased. During the week I do cross training which involves: cycling, shorter runs, circut training, body balance, yoga and pilates.

HALF MARATHON Sunday 3 March 2013: 13.1 Miles 

Just home after finishing the Eastbourne half marathon! Loved the crowds and drummers cheering us on in the cold (didn't love the big hill up to beachy head!!) 6 weeks till the Brighton marathon!

 

 

Monday 11 March 2013: 15 Miles

Just back from a FROSTY 15 mile training run in blizzard conditions. Brighton was hit with driving snow + 35km winds which bought the temperature of -1 down to feel like -7 degrees. It turns out today is the coldest March day on record for 27 years. After this run i feel like i can handle anything! 5 weeks to go

 
Sunday 17 March 2013: 17 Miles
This was the hardest run i've ever done. Heavy rain and strong winds made it a tough day out on the road and i'm totally exhausted. Thanks so much for your support. It really means a lot. 4 weeks to go.
 
 
Sunday 25 March: 20 Miles
The weather here in the UK is still like mid-winter with temperatures hovering around zero and snow on the way again! Today's run was especially tough not only as it was the longest run i've ever done in my life but also because my body is really starting to feel the pain :(
 
The supportive exchange of a simple nod, wave, smile with others out pounding the pavement to train for the marathon helps, but your support for this cause is why I keep running, so a big heartfelt THANKS for your contributions. 3 weeks to go!! 
 
Wednesday 27th March: Physio
After Sunday's 20 mile run my right knee was giving me a lot of pain so I went to see a physio where i was told I have a suspected tear to my knee cartilage which, if it is, will require key hole surgery to remove which means my marathon hopes are in doubt :(
 
Thanks so much for your support to get me to this point, I really still hope to make it to the marathon. After all this training i'll be so upset if it doesn't happen. I will let you know how things progress
 
Sunday 31st March: 8 Miles 
Today's run was a test for my knee. It still hurts but I managed to run 8 miles even if very slowly! I've now had some Nurofen and it's helped a lot! Luckily I have done all the long runs i had planned to do for my training and now i'm in the tapering phase. Rest and recovery are in order to try and help my knee. 2 weeks to go.
 
Sunday 7th April: 8 Miles
What a difference a week makes. I've had a break from training and my knee feels stronger. Today's run was much happier than last weeks and it helped that the sun came out to say hello :) So despite my dodgy knee I've decided to get stuck in and give it my best shot!  
 
Your support, which will help to give Evander a chance to walk, is really appreciated and has genuinely helped keep me focused and motivated. Thankyou.
 
For anyone wanting to follow my progress on the day, via the Brighton Marathon app,  my race number is 13465. 
 
Brighton Marathon 2013 on Sunday 14th April starts at 9am.
 
6 days to go.
 
Jen.x
 
 
Sunday 14th April 2013: 26.2 Miles/42.2km
Mission Accomplished!! What a day, what an event and what amazing crowds! It was so physically and mentally tough but i made it!  
 
The day started with drizzly rain which soon cleared up to a sunny/cloudy 12 degrees. I started off well and felt good but by mile 20 I was in pieces and thinking i'd have to walk the rest of the way. I gave myself a good talking to and managed to get running again to the finish. What a brilliant feeling it was to cross the line. 
 
Thankyou so much to everyone who supported and sponsored my efforts, I honestly couldn't and wouldn't have made it without you.
 
Today I feel happy, proud, exhausted and humbled by the incredible support you've all shown. Thankyou.
 
Evander - I wish you every succes for America. To keep a track of Evander's progress you can follow him via the Evander Conroy Foundation website:
 
http://www.evanderconroyfoundation.org.au/

story:
(Ver texto en español abajo, el video en español en nuestra galería o aquí: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bSH8r2piCfY)

Maní+: Fighting Malnutrition and Supporting Farmers

Guatemala is a country rich in natural resources and great ethnic and cultural diversity.  It is a country with great potential.

Yet, Guatemala suffers from the highest index of chronic malnutrition in Latin America and the third highest in the world. Almost half of all Guatemalan children under five will be stunted for life due to lack of an adequate diet.  Among the rural Maya population, those figures are even higher.

We are a group of diverse professions and backgrounds based in Guatemala City dedicated to solving this problem and giving Guatemalan children a chance for a better future.

We were tired of reading reports year after year about malnutrition with no improvement, so we developed an efficient and effective solution to prevent malnutrition in infants and children now! 

What does Maní+ do?

Maní+ offers an innovative and holistic approach to combating malnutrition in Guatemala while providing economic development opportunities for rural farmers in communities affected by malnutrition. 

We have developed a tasty paste, known as an RUSF, made from local ingredients and enriched with a custom mixture of vitamins and minerals that precisely targets the needs of Guatemalan kids. It is accompanied by an education program for mothers delivered in their native languages.

Our model is based on financial sustainability through sales at affordable prices, with surplus revenues invested in expansion and new product development.

What are we raising funds for?

We are about to launch our pilot project to evaluate and improve our product and educational model. This is a key step to producing the RUSF on a large scale and effectively reducing the index of malnutrition. The pilot project consists of distributing the RUSF to the mothers of children who are at risk of chronic malnutrition, providing a culturally-specific participant-learning model, follow-up, and support. The goal of the pilot is to evaluate use and acceptability of the RUSF so we can make the appropriate changes before we produce on a large scale. All of the children involved will receive full treatment free of cost.

This is an essential step to becoming the first social enterprise that is producing RUSFs locally, identifying effective distribution channels and improving our model before large-scale production. Looking at effective social enterprises such as Ecofiltro and Grameen-Danone as models, we believe that producing RUSFs using a social enterprise model is the most efficient, effective and sustainable way to prevent and treat malnutrition in Guatemala, today!

 

Will you join the fight against hunger?

Learn more here: www.maniplus.org

or write: info@maniplus.org

 

ESPAÑOL

Maní +: Combatiendo la Desnutrición y Apoyando a los Agricultores

Guatemala es un país rico en recursos naturales y con una gran diversidad étnica y cultural. Es un país con un gran potencial.

Sin embargo, Guatemala sufre del mayor índice de desnutrición crónica en América Latina y el tercero más alto del mundo. Casi la mitad de los niños guatemaltecos menores de cinco años presentan retraso en el crecimiento físico y cognitivo como resultado de una dieta inadecuada, lo cual puede resultar en bajo rendimiento en la escuela y en limitar oportunidades de empleo en el futuro. Los indígenas en el área rural son los más afectados.

Somos un grupo de diverso basado en la ciudad de Guatemala dedicado a la solución de este problema y dar a los niños guatemaltecos la oportunidad de un futuro mejor.

Estábamos cansados de leer año tras año informes sobre desnutrición sin ningún cambio, por lo que hemos desarrollado una solución eficiente y eficaz para prevenir la desnutrición en infantes y niños ahora!

¿Que es Maní+?

Maní + ofrece un enfoque innovador e integral para combatir la desnutrición en Guatemala mientras que proporciona oportunidades de desarrollo económico para los agricultores de las zonas rurales en las comunidades afectadas por la desnutrición.

Hemos desarrollado una pasta sabrosa, conocida como RUSF, elaborada con ingredientes locales y enriquecida con una mezcla de vitaminas y minerales que ayuda a satisfacer las necesidades específicas de los niños guatemaltecos. El alimento complementario es acompañado de un programa de educación para madres impartido en sus idiomas nativos, empoderándolas para tomar buenas decisiones nutricionales.

Nuestro modelo está basado en alcanzar sostenibilidad financiera a través de las ventas a precios accesibles, con excedentes invertidos en la expansión y el desarrollo de nuevos productos. 

¿Para qué estamos recaudando fondos?

Maní + ha demostrado ser eficaz en el laboratorio, pero ahora tenemos que evaluar su uso en el campo y el trabajo con madres para mejorar nuestro modelo educativo en idiomas maternos. El proyecto piloto consiste en distribuir el RUSF a las madres de los niños que están en riesgo de desnutrición crónica, proporcionándoles un modelo de educación culturalmente específico, su seguimiento y apoyo. Todos los niños participantes recibirán un tratamiento completo de forma gratuita.

Este es un paso esencial para convertirse en la primera empresa social que se está produciendo RUSFs localmente. Tomamos como ejemplo los modelos de las empresas sociales exitosas, tales como Ecofiltro y Grameen Danone. Creemos que la producción de RUSFs mediante un modelo de empresa social es la forma más eficiente, eficaz y sostenible para prevenir y tratar la desnutrición en Guatemala, hoy!

 

¿Y tu te apuntas a la lucha contra el hambre?

Más información aquí: www.maniplus.org

o escribe a: info@maniplus.org

or write: info@maniplus.org
 
ESPAÑOL
Maní +: Combatiendo la Desnutrición y Apoyando a los Agricultores
Guatemala es un país rico en recursos naturales y con una gran diversidad étnica y cultural. Es un país con un gran potencial.
Sin embargo, Guatemala sufre del mayor índice de desnutrición crónica en América Latina y el tercero más alto del mundo. Casi la mitad de los niños guatemaltecos menores de cinco años presentan retraso en el crecimiento físico y cognitivo como resultado de una dieta inadecuada, lo cual puede resultar en bajo rendimiento en la escuela y en limitar oportunidades de empleo en el futuro. Los indígenas en el área rural son los más afectados.
Somos un grupo de diverso basado en la ciudad de Guatemala dedicado a la solución de este problema y dar a los niños guatemaltecos la oportunidad de un futuro mejor.
Estábamos cansados de leer año tras año informes sobre desnutrición sin ningún cambio, por lo que hemos desarrollado una solución eficiente y eficaz para prevenir la desnutrición en infantes y niños ahora!
¿Que es Maní+?
Maní + ofrece un enfoque innovador e integral para combatir la desnutrición en Guatemala mientras que proporciona oportunidades de desarrollo económico para los agricultores de las zonas rurales en las comunidades afectadas por la desnutrición.
Hemos desarrollado una pasta sabrosa, conocida como RUSF, elaborada con ingredientes locales y enriquecida con una mezcla de vitaminas y minerales que ayuda a satisfacer las necesidades específicas de los niños guatemaltecos. El alimento complementario es acompañado de un programa de educación para madres impartido en sus idiomas nativos, empoderándolas para tomar buenas decisiones nutricionales.
Nuestro modelo está basado en alcanzar sostenibilidad financiera a través de las ventas a precios accesibles, con excedentes invertidos en la expansión y el desarrollo de nuevos productos. 
¿Para qué estamos recaudando fondos?
Maní + ha demostrado ser eficaz en el laboratorio, pero ahora tenemos que evaluar su uso en el campo y el trabajo con madres para mejorar nuestro modelo educativo en idiomas maternos. El proyecto piloto consiste en distribuir el RUSF a las madres de los niños que están en riesgo de desnutrición crónica, proporcionándoles un modelo de educación culturalmente específico, su seguimiento y apoyo. Todos los niños participantes recibirán un tratamiento completo de forma gratuita.
Este es un paso esencial para convertirse en la primera empresa social que se está produciendo RUSFs localmente. Tomamos como ejemplo los modelos de las empresas sociales exitosas, tales como Ecofiltro y Grameen Danone. Creemos que la producción de RUSFs mediante un modelo de empresa social es la forma más eficiente, eficaz y sostenible para prevenir y tratar la desnutrición en Guatemala, hoy!
 
¿Y tu te apuntas a la lucha contra el hambre?
Más información aquí: www.maniplus.org

o escribe a: info@maniplus.org

story:
My Name is, Monica. My Husband, Son and I HATE to, - but find ourselves needing to, - ask for help from friends, Family, and Kind-Hearted strangers

our dear sweet Daughter Alexa ( 9 yrs. Young) is in a fight for her life with Cancer - Alexa has (Inoperable Brain Cancer) We hate asking for help, but this journey is bigger financially than all of us.

We have been searching for any cure we can find. We have been to TX, then New York. Hopeful for a trial med there, Alexa experienced every side effect of the trial drug, Rashes, blood counts, No appetite, weight loss, and STILL the trial did not work on her tumor. If anything, it made it grow.

We then knew there was one more trial that was still open that she would qualiffy for. We flew as fast as we could to Boston MA. We enrolled in the trial. This Med. has worked on many other kinds of tumors. Now we will see if it will shrink a complicated tumor such as Alexa's  ( it is an NF (Neurofibromatosis) Optic Glioma) - mixed with Cancer too.

We started the trial and she was only on it for two days when the Growth from the New York trials failure caught up with Alexa. It caused irreputable damage.

 She had for the very 1st time seizures, She has had 9 brain surgeries, (5 of them just in the past 2 months)  3 port surgeries, G-tube surgery, NG tube, Shunt, EVD, Hydrocephalus, port sticks, & two Blood transfusions - The Hydrocephalus took the rest of her sight and rendered her BLIND              (On Friday April 13th 2012) 

We need to raise money to get to and from Boston MA. for a special trial medication that could shrink our Daughter's Brain Tumor.
PLEASE anything you donate can make a difference. even $1  
GOD BLESS ALL OF YOU!  ........ THANK YOU!                                          Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean that you can’t help,

You can please PASS THIS LINK FOR THIS CAMPAIGN TO EVERYONE YOU CAN!     Just  use the Indiegogo share tools for easy access.

THE MONEY RAISED will Pay for travel expenses to and from Boston for the next year, and will help Keep food on our family table and a roof over our heads.  --------------------------------

You can Pray (Please email prayers so I can read them to her)   Lexyprincess03@aol.com

Give whatever you can give. (EVEN $1) 1000 people give $1 and we have made our goal.

God Bless you for everything for reading, praying and Blessings on all of you forever. Please tell all your friends and family or anyone who may be able to help. We are so embarrassed to ask for help, but our Daughter's life is so precious to us.

For those who wish to follow Alexa's Journey right along with us, please visit her CARE PAGE: www.carepages.com/princessalexasdaybyday

to Join her facebook: Princess Lexy (Alexa Naomi delos Reyes)

THANK YOU !!!! Alexa sends her love & (((HUGS)))

 

THE MUSIC ON THIS VIDEO is called "LULLABY FOR ALEXA"

it is off the album "THE ONE I WAITED FOR" By MICHAEL DULIN

With His Permission we are able to play this music on our Video.

God Bless You Mr. Dulin . Your Kindness is a Blessing in our lives <3

story:
Our Goal

It's pretty simple really:

  • We want to locally donate (Raleigh/Durham, NC) to those in need for the upcoming 2012 holiday season.
  • We're going to grow ridiculous (magnificent?) beards for at least a month to entice our co-workers (and maybe others!) to fork over cash in exchange for smiling faces.
  • Weekly photo updates will be posted on Monday afternoons, along with total donation amounts for each bearded warrior (for those that can endure the challenge, at least)
  • Prior pictures will be added to the gallery, so that participants can go back to see how un-manly they once looked.
  • Our journey ends on October 30th, 2012, and we're proud to say that all proceeds will go to InterAct of Wake County.
  • You can pledge your support for as little as $1 per vote, and are welcome to make multiple donations thoughout the duration of the campaign.

The Combatants - Week 5 Pictures

(donation standings as of 10/31/12 - FINAL)

- 1st - Chris Hoskins - $200

- 2nd - Selma Pittman - $195

- 3rd - Eric Gressel - $175

- 4th - Gary Barrier - $125

- 5th - Dave Priel - $85

- 6th - Josh Jamieson - $63

- 7th - Chris Floyd - $60

- 8th - Blake Brown - $49

*Sadly, Blake could not complete the journey with us due to Halloween conflicts, but we shall always know him as "half-beard"

- 9th - Tommy Cooksey - $45

- 10th - Ryan Blair - $37

The Rules

  • October 1st - Shave all existing facial hair
  • October 2nd through 30th - DON'T Shave (Neck beards or "Neards" may be groomed)
  • The VICTOR will be the one who fetches the most coin, and his reward shall be the satisfaction and new confidence gained from being "beardly". The victor will also be free to either sustain or terminate his relationship with his furry new friend as he wishes.
  • The LOSERS will be at the mercy of their most charitable personal contributor (henceforth known as "Master"), and must style their facial hair in the manner that their Master wishes for a period of at least one (1) full working day in the office.
  • If a person cannot make the full journey he may bow out gracefully, but will live forever in shame, be shunned by his co-workers, and might occasionally be called "sissy".

story:
Our Story

If you ever been to show at Warehouse Live, you've probably met Amy Marie Shields.  She checked your id, she scanned your ticket, she probably asked how you were doing and then gave you a big welcoming smile like she always does.  But that's not all Amy is or does.  She's probably the reason that you even knew there was a show that night.  She runs the twitter account, sets up the facebook pages and emails you to let you know your favorite band is coming to town.  In summary, if you've enjoyed a concert at Warehouse Live, it probably had a lot to do with Amy Marie Shields.


Well, our good friend Amy is in pain and needs surgery.  And soon.


What We Need

We are trying to help Amy get this surgery she needs.  The doctors will not schedule or perform her surgery without an advance payment of $6061.72.  This sucks, but unfortunately, its the world we live in today.  Amy needs some help.  Without this procedure, Amy will continue to hurt and continue to get sicker.


I'm working on ways to incentive folks to donate, but time is of the essence.  I promise something cool for your donation.  Trust me.


Every single dollar counts.  If you've got a couple of extra bucks to spare, please do.  We need to raise this money as soon as possible.


I will match the first $1000 of donations made.


Other Ways You Can Help

Got another way you think you can help?  Please do not hesitate to email me.  mark.c.austin@gmail.com

story:
My story...

For the last couple of years I have been learning more about myself and have recognized that I am transgender/genderqueer. I identify as gender-neutral and have began going by the name C to reflect this.

Ever since my chest began developing at the beginning of puberty, I have not felt comfortable with it. I've known that someday I would have my breasts removed, but it's taken a while to figure out the right time. At the beginning of this year I decided that 2012 is the year I will have the surgery. This surgery will allow me to feel a lot more comfortable - my body will match who I really am inside.

I set the goal amount for my Indiegogo campaign for less than the actual cost of my surgery in order to reduce the chance of not acheiving my goal.  Although, I still recieve any amount whether it's under or over my goal.  The whole surgery is going to cost $6-7,000+. I do not have insurance but even if I did it likely would not make a difference, as most insurance companies don't cover surgery related to transgender health. I have some funds saved, which is a start to covering the costs, and am hoping to raise some money in order to help cover the difference. I If you aren't able to donate money, no problem - your support truly means the world to me.

Thanks to everyone who has been supporting me through this part of my life, I can't thank you enough.

with much love,

C

story:
THE STORY

The beginning:


Shamanic practitioner Gale Conroy was first diagnosed with triple negative breast cancer in 2008.  After recovering from breast cancer the second time, Gale and her husband Craig sold their house, put their backpacks on and went half way round the world on a trip to heal and help people in need.  They travelled to Africa, Australia, South America, Hawaii and Thailand, broadening their shamanic skills with the aim to come home and work with people in the UK.

 

On their trip from Australia to Thailand, Gale was finding it difficult to walk and when her condition worsened, doctors in Thailand told her to go home and seek medical attention for an infection in her hip.  Within two hours of returning to the UK her hip joint broke and she was rushed to hospital. Gale was given a hip replacement and a few weeks later she received the earth shattering news that her breast cancer spread to her bone, skull and lung.


The Hospital Cancer Treatment:

 

After researching into Gale’s type of cancer to see what options were available for treatment, Craig was delighted to discover a fantastic private hospital in Germany, Fachklinik Dr. Herzog.  The hospital combines the latest and most successful treatment that science has to offer along with the best of holistic cancer treatment as well.

 

Gale is undergoing Whole Body Hyperthermia and chemotherapy in Germany to help her fight against the cancer in her body. Due to her weak health condition and receiving treatment in Germany money is in short supply and medical bills are already beginning to mount.

 

Everyone who has met Gale is devastated by the news of her illness and we all want to help her FIGHT against this terrible disease.  Gale is constantly helping others, so now is the time to give her a little help as well.  Gale’s Fighting Fund has been set up to help her continue to receive the medical treatment that she needs and deserves.


GALE

As a massage therapist and healer, Gale brightens the lives of adults and children on a day-to-day basis. She is a mother, wife, teacher and friend and is known to many as fellow glamper, festival diva, hippy chick and fashionista.   

 

She is a ray of sunshine and lights up the room everywhere she goes, including the hospital where she is meant to be recovering! She has inspired many people around the world with her shamanic approach and homeopathic therapy.

 

Craig and Gale’s ultimate goal is to open their own healing sanctuary to help people in the UK.  Gale loves her work and no matter what the situation, she never runs out of time for others. Every day she uses her strength and determination to battle this disease and her bravery is truly inspirational.

 

WHAT WE NEED

Gale is currently receiving treatment in a Cancer Clinic in Germany, which specialises in her type of condition. We do not have an estimated recovery period at this time, but we hope she can keep receiving her treatment for as long as possible.  Our projected costs for her treatment, travel and recovery period is at least £100,000, but in all likelihood, considerably more. Friends and family are planning to raise money through fundraising events, private gigs, sponsored runs, swims, cycling and much more.  Through “Gale’s Fighting Fund” we are hoping to raise as much money as possible and our target is to raise at least £15,000.


HOW ELSE YOU CAN HELP

 

Over the next few months we will be running, swimming and holding a range of events to raise money for Gale’s Fighting Fund.

 

Please let us know if you are fundraising on our Facebook page or simply spread the word.

 

We appreciate all your efforts and thank you in advance.

story:
Comper returns to indiegogo with Smarkin, the most awesome smart-skincare device ever.

Utilizing the best and newest technology, the Smarkin smart skincare tool not only reverses the tolls of aging, but heals and rejuvenates your skin with RF, EMS, MASS, and LED.

A smart solution for aging, scarred, or dull skin; the Smarkin tool can heal, rejuvenate, and plan out better skincare routines that are precisely customized for you. Combining advanced technology to treat your skin and track your progress, the Smarkin will customize and revolutionize your skin’s health and appearance.

Benefit from using Smarkin for extensive skin problems

 

Comper returns to Indiegogo with the most awesome smart skincare device ever.

 

One is All

The Comper Smarkin device integrates technologies including RF, EMS, LED, and micro vibrational therapy into one new, top-of-the-line approach for treating your skin. It firms the face and reduces wrinkles, acne, fat, and other skin defects in an actionable, intelligent way.

Real Smart  Skincare Solution

By providing seamless interfacing between the device and the app, Smarkin delivers a customized skincare solution that does so much more than just treat your skin. The app can guide each individual user to better understanding their skin health and managing it more comprehensively.

 

Comper Health App smartly interfaces your skin with the Smarkin

 

Smarkin Overview  

 

Comper Health App overview  

Skin Health Matters 

Our skin is the largest organ of our integumentary system. It’s the most exposed to the environment, and therefore plays an important immunity role in protecting our body against pathogens and excessive water loss.

Aging skin is defined as a reduction of volume and elasticity, with clinical findings like sagging, wrinkles, and various facets of photoaging that are caused by a variety of internal and external factors.

The effects of aging on the skin not only influences our overall health and functionality, but also our outward appearance, impacting our work environments, our careers, and our social lives.

 

Do I Need a Comper Smarkin ?

No matter your age and gender, you may be aware that your skin needs that “extra mile” to look younger, healthier, and more attractive. This makes the Comper Smarkin perfect for you.

If you feel disheartened about your aging skin or if you suffer from the issues listed below, you can certainly benefit from using the Comper Smarkin as both a treatment and a prophylaxis.

 

How Smarkin works?

The process initiates your personal skincare routine

Efficient Treatment by the Large Surface  

The treatment surface is designed as 53.4 mm in diameter, with the circular electrodes being 51.2mm and 12.81 mm each. This coverage ensures that each lifting or circling operation on your face is done with the utmost efficiency. No need for lengthy application processes!

Treat more by a less time

Fully Covered in Medical-grade Silicon Rubber

The body of this device is wrapped with medical-grade silicon rubber, which brings Smarkin to an IPX6 resistant level. You’ll experience added stability even when the device (or your grip) is damp, such as when you use it with our HA gel or right after a shower.

Comfort and stability in hand

 

4 in1 Enhanced Technologies   

 

Radio Frequency, EMS(Electric muscle Stimulation), LED(Low-Level-Light-Laser Therapy) and MASS(Micro Vibrational Massage)

3 Levels of Radio Frequency (RF)

With three (3) levels of radio frequency to switch between, the two (2) circular electrodes will produce a seamless electromagnetic field that affects about 4mm of depth in your skin. 

What does this mean, exactly? The “radio frequency skin tightening” is a scientifically-approved aesthetic technology, which reduces fine lines and loosens your skin. That is accomplished by using electromagnetic energy to heat your skin tissue, thereby encouraging your skin to produce subdermal collagen that can remodel said tissue to be brand-new.

Not real shooting but a demo of amplified anti-wrinkle result

3 Levels of Micro-current (EMS)

The circular electrodes also generate micro-currents, with three (3) intensities to switch between. This will elicit muscle contractions on different levels. What does that mean in practice? Your skin will get a type of workout, which results in several therapeutic effects such as muscle toning and facial lifting.

The current waveform( shape of changing voltage ) is square that has similar effect to the face pumping .

Not real shooting but a demo of a amplified face-firming result

LED, both Red and Near-infrared  

Smarkin produces both 630 nm and 850nm wavelengths in light energy, which will penetrate the skin at around a 1.5-2.5mm depth. The spectral range (from 630 to 850) was reported and widely accepted to be extremely beneficial in reducing wrinkles and acne scars, as well as healing burns, UV damage, pigment disorders like vitiligo, and inflammatory diseases like psoriasis and acne.

The photons that Smarkin emits in different wavelengths will be absorbed by mitochondrial chromophores in your skin cells. This causes successful reactions in releasing ATP, which reactivates oxygen species and increases tissue repair and healing.

That’s a lot of medical-speak, so what does it really mean? Your skin will literally absorb the light energy and give up its imperfections as a response!

MASS with The Best Frequency  

Comper Smarkin generates the most efficient and comfortable micro-vibration frequency, which amplifies the beneficial effects of creams you use, while also boosting micro-circulation under the dermis. In short, your skin will be healthier overall, allowing it to better receive other types of skin treatment from your normal routines!

Intelligence Brings Individuality  

Like tree leaves and snowflakes, everyone's skin is unique. Comper Smarkin is designed to figure out the most suitable skincare routine for each individual user – one that can be dynamically adjusted to suit the changes of your skin or unique physical conditions like skin types, skin disorders, periods, and allergies.

To accomplish this, you can test your skin type on the Comper Health App. Then, a personal skincare schedule with reset functions will be generated and sent to your Smarkin device.

The Comper Health App also has particular skincare options pre-set for individuals, which can be chosen and adjusted to better guide the user in solving certain facial conditions like wrinkles, sagging, acne, fat, dullness, and more.

For those experienced with advanced skincare, Comper Smarkin makes all the setting authorities open to users, allowing them to configure their own skincare routines to fit their unique needs or technology preferences.

Get your long-term skincare solution through a professional skin type test

Comper Health App also preset specific skincare options for individuals, that can be choosing and adjusting for guiding the user to solve some certain facial conditions like the wrinkle, sagging, acne, fat, dull and other facial problems. 

For the seniors in skincare, Comper Smarkin opens all the setting authorities to allow the users to configure their own skincare routines as their certain needs or technology preferences.

Perfect Interfacing with Your Skin

The Comper Smarkin device plays the perfect middle-man between your skin and the app. It’s on standby to utilize and perform each new combination of technology (from the app) and unique preferences or insights (from you), so that you get the most intelligent and personalized experience.

Interface based on your skin type  

There are certain skin types - like oily, sensitive, or wrinkled – that fit certain pre-set skincare options. As such, the device can provide customized treatment for those issues. Take a few minutes to complete an all-inclusive test in the Comper Health App, and you’ll receive a personal, long-term skincare routine that can be put into action immediately.

 

Shortcuts to your dream skin   

We all have certain skincare goals to achieve, such eliminating wrinkles, erasing the effects of acne, lifting, illuminating, or hydrating. The Comper Health App has four (4) pre-set skincare modes, which are result-oriented with adjustable options.

More options  for  senior users  

If you are experienced with using smart technology for your skincare needs, or if you’re a veteran of skincare tools, then the “Senior Mode” will be a base on which you can create your own personalized skincare routine – with unlimited control!

 

Comprehend Your Skin Changes

Great skincare technology is all about the results. You’ll not only be impressed by the clear improvements in your skin when you look in the mirror (both in the short- and long-term), but you can enjoy the fundamental improvements on a microscopic level. The Comper Health App will detail those below-the-surface changes that ensure your skin is legitimately becoming healthier with each session.

Better understand the changes to your skin 

  Trust what the mirror tells you – but trust our smart technology to tell you even more. With this device, you can better understand the changes in your face’s ATP, collagen, elastin, fat, growth factor, water, microcirculation, and even the DNA repairs within your skin tissues. These factors are calculated based on the voltage of Smarkin’s micro-currents, the range of its radio frequency, and the duration of each session completed by our device.

Statistically present you detailed changes in a microscopic mechanism

Get inspired by your skin's age 

By calculating and tracking your skin’s aging process, our device allows you to view the reverse-aging process that goes on with your daily use of the Smarkin.

Comper HA Essence  

Comper provides medical-quality HA essence (a.k.a., Hyaluronic Acid gel), instead of ordinary skincare gel. This results in better electric conduction for the treatment that the device itself provides, while also moisturizing your skin during the session.

Comper HA Sheet Mask

Want to save time? Looking to maximize the results? By using the Smarkin’s customized “Mask Mode” with the Comper HA Sheet Mask, you can minimize the time each session requires, while amplifying the benefits. This is thanks to the sheet mask’s ability to better conduct the LED and RF qualities of the device, while also rapidly hydrating your skin.

Fool-Proof Operation  

The video and voice guide within the app will effortlessly lead you through the process of correctly applying treatment. There’s no guessing and no room for mistakes; you’ll know exactly where to guide the device and which gestures will produce the best results.

Colors for you

 

Why Smarkin Differs from Others  

 

 

 

Follow Us

 

Milestones

Beauty Creator

Du Han, funder & CEO of Comper

Du is a female serial entrepreneur who has a passion for developing the digital healthcare industry. She is a graduate of the Capital University of Medical Science. With twelve years of experience in the medical industry, Du founded Comper Healthcare, where she serves as a chief agent of orthopedic consumables and heart stents for LEPU Medical. She is also Co-Founder of Regent Capital, an investor in PING AN HEALTH, and has been nominated for the Women in Investment Awards 2018 and Business Women's Awards 2018.

Nice Meeting You Again

Comper‘s Awards  

Smarkin’s parent company, Comper, has been fortunate to receive a number of awards. Our most recent accolades include:

Comper's Vision

As a part of Comper's vision for Making Body Data Easy to Get and Use, we are dedicated to utilizing data in a smart, actionable way and visualizing your skin health for comprehensive management.

Referral Program

We are also opening up a referral program that you can participate in and earn commissions for helping us spread the word! you can contact BD@comper.com for more information.

Risks and challenges

We believe that any project or idea comes with its own risks and challenges. In the first stage, our challenge was to bring this device to life - and we did it! As for other risks, we believe that they are almost nonexistent, as this is our third campaign. The only complication may be the shipping time, though we are working to ensure that our backers will receive their devices on time – the same as usual!

Comper returns to indiegogo with Smarkin, the most awesome smart-skincare device ever.

A smart solution for aging, scarred, or dull skin; the Smarkin tool can heal, rejuvenate, and plan out better skincare routines that are precisely customized for you. story:
Crowd-funded Research

Resistant Starch Analysis

Resistant starch (RS) is under intense examination as a health aid. It's a special type of fiber that promises great health impacts, as you'll soon read. Until now, RS has been under the control of the food industry who uses RS as an ingredient in processed foods.

There is little written about the exact potency of RS as found in common cooking starches. Many people use these starches as supplements, and researchers use them in medical studies, yet, few have tested them for RS content. This is a BIG DEAL.

I am raising funds to send numerous samples of starches to a certified lab for testing. These tests will show us the true nature of RS and the best sources to get it from.

Please read below for some background on RS and the issues surrounding it.

 

For those unfamiliar with resistant starch

Resistant What? Resistant starch!

Also known as RS, this special type of dietary fiber may hold the key to our lasting health. Resistant starch is recognized globally as a key contributor to regaining blood sugar control and many other health benefits. Both the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) allow health claims to be made on processed food items which contain RS.

Medical studies on the health effects of RS utilize several types of commercially available starches such as potato, Hi-Maize, or green banana flour. Unfortunately, there are no starches sold that are labeled with the RS content. 

I have advocated supplementing with RS since 2012. In these years, many thousands of people have begun using raw potato starch or another source. The majority of people report beneficial effects (better glucose control, sleep, bowel movements, reduced inflammation, etc.), but a few people have complained of "no" or "negative" effects such as joint pain, mood swings, or digestive discomfort. A 2017 review of 30 years of RS research indicates that researchers around the world see these same results, and blame the inconsistencies on personal differences of the gut biome. I believe that differences in RS sources might also be to blame.

Background on RS

Resistant starch is a type of starch that "resists" digestion. It passes through the stomach and small intestine undigested and enters the large intestine where it serves as a food source for gut bacteria. This is also the definition of a "prebiotic." Please watch this short video:

 

Getting RS from whole foods is difficult. Resistant starch is found abundantly in in potatoes, beans, and green bananas, but most of the RS is destroyed in the cooking process, so these foods need to be consumed raw. Research indicates that we need 10-40 grams of RS daily to reap the benefits...equivalent to the RS found in 2 green bananas or a small, raw potato.

Dietary sources of RS, ie. cooked potatoes and  beans, supply only 3-5 grams of RS at best. However, raw starches as found in the cooking aisle of any supermarket may be used as an RS supplement. One tablespoon of potato starch contains about 7 grams of RS. Green Banana Flour contains about 5 grams. The problem with using these starches as a dietary supplement is that they have not been tested for RS contents and different starch extraction processes may destroy the RS. Besides potatoes and bananas, a plethora of common starches are available that may also contain RS. Arrowroot, green banana, tapioca, sweet potato, mung bean, kuzu root, and sago palm are all also shown to be high in RS.

Types of Resistant Starch

RS has been classified into five general types named RS1–RS5, but this project is only concerned with type 2 (RS2). This is the RS found in raw starches and suitable for use as a dietary supplement.

Under a microscope, RS2 looks like this:

RS2 is in raw starch granules, sometimes called “native starch.” These starch granules are protected from digestion by the structure and composition of the starch granule itself. The structure of the starch granules have an impact on the resistance of the starch. Their compact nature prevents digestive enzymes and stomach acids from attacking the starch allowing it to reach the large intestine whole.  RS2 is found in potatoes, green bananas, plantains, taro, cassava, and in most cereal grains. Not all raw starch is resistant starch. Corn, wheat, and rice starch, for instance are readily digestible for the most part.

Boring stuff, right?  Well, read on!

Effects of RS

Hundreds of studies have been conducted over the last 30 years on the effects of RS to:

  • Improve bowel health
  • Correct the pH of the Intestines
  • Increase the thickness of the bowel wall (a good thing!)
  • Kill cancer cells
  • Lower postprandial glycemia
  • Increase insulin sensitivity
  • Reduce body weight and prevent weight regain
  • Decrease inflammation in the intestines and entire body
  • Reduce risk of breast cancer and colorectal cancer
  • Reduce cholesterol/triglycerides
  • Increase production of brain neurotransmitters serotonin and melatonin
  • Remove certain pathogens from small intestine
  • Preserve Vitamin D in the body
  • Increase mineral and vitamin production and uptake
  • Remove toxins and heavy metals from the bloodstream
  • Increase satiety and regulate hunger hormones
  • Reduce fat storage after meals
  • Improve the gut microbiome (synergy, prebiotic, symbiotic)
  • Protect probiotic bacteria

There are currently about 40 clinical trials registered with ClinicalTrials.gov examining the effects of resistant starch, most using RS2. Nearly all researchers use potato starch or Hi-Maize corn starch, simply because they are unaware of other suitable sources.

The Need for Analysis

With all of these studied health benefits, the only people able to supply us with RS are food manufacturers who can put RS into our biscuits, spaghetti, and bread. There are a few RS supplements being sold as dietary aids, but they do not list the RS content of the product, only the source. I have spoken directly with the makers of most products sold as RS supplements, and most have indicated that they do not test their products. This analysis will be of great help to the manufacturers of RS products to more accurately label and recommend a dosage. It will also steer them away from starches that contain low amounts of RS.

 

What I'm Looking For...

I'm hoping to develop a database of the RS2 contents in various starches. At the present time, no one has any idea what the true RS value of a random raw starch is, and few are willing to spend $200 to test. 

If we discover that most starches tested are nowhere near their hypothetical values in RS, then we can say that using raw starches is not appropriate for supplementation.  Perhaps we will find differences between manufacturers.  If this is the case, then we will be aware that more testing is required to ensure batch consistency.

However, we may also find that all samples of certain starches are high in RS and have no issues with safety and quality. In this case, consumers and researchers will have confidence in choosing off-the-shelf raw starches for their supplementation and experimental needs.

Conclusion

This project is the first ever to test multiple batches and various types of food-grade starch thought to be high in resistant starch. I will make the most of every dollar to ensure we get the most complete and useful tests.

Thank you for backing my project. This is good science, done completely outside the influence of food manufacturers.

For researchers and those familiar with RS

Resistant starch type 2 (RS2) contents of food-grade starches.

High Amylose Maize Starch (Hi-Maize), raw potato starch (RPS), and green banana flour (GBF) are universally accepted as excellent sources of RS2. Supplement manufacturers now put these three starches into consumer products and label them as resistant starch. Many doctors recommend supplementing with these starches to increase prebiotic fiber in the diet. However, manufacturers are not required to test and label these products with their RS content, and only Hi-Maize is produced with RS in mind. Manufacturing processes could destroy the RS2 if heat is applied during extraction. This represents a huge problem and could explain the variable individual responses seen in many RS2 studies. My goal is to categorize the amount of RS2 found in off-the-shelf food-grade starches from around the world and explore the RS2 content of other food-grade starches known to be high in RS2 (ie. tapioca, arrowroot, sweet potato, kuzu, mung bean, and sago). When complete, we will have a complete picture of the RS2 content in the most commonly used RS2 sources and possibly discover some others. If enough money is generated, and enough tests can be completed, the results of this project will be written up for publication to aid future researchers, supplement manufacturers, and health practitioners.

Background

Despite 30 years of research into RS health benefits, there are no supplements available that have been tested and labeled with their RS content. Though food manufacturers have developed several types of RS to act as a functional ingredient in processed foods (RS4 and RS5), it's type two RS (RS2) that is used in most studies, clinical trials, and as supplements. RS2 is a natural, unmodified ingredient that resonates well with people wishing to use an all-natural fiber supplement. The nature of RS2 can change drastically with the addition of heat, and many starches are extracted with processes that require heat. For instance, potatoes are blasted with hot water or steam to remove the peels, and green bananas may be cooked to enable easier peeling. HAMS, sold as Hi-Maize, is a very stable product, yet it also is not labeled with its RS content when sold as a cooking item or consumer supplement. The RS2 in potatoes and green bananas is different among cultivars and ripeness, further complicating matters. Consumers and researchers wishing to use these three RS2 sources rely on faith that their particular batch is a good source of RS2. Hi-Maize is the only RS2 source specifically manufactured to contain a significant amount of RS2.

Health Claims

With the FDA's 2016 allowance of RS health claims on food labels, more emphasis will be placed on sources of RS in the diet. My intent is to create a resource that can be used by nutritionists, researchers, supplement manufacturers, and people wishing to increase their RS intake. At present, the FDA's claim is only applicable to foods containing Hi-Maize. If this ruling is to be extended to other natural sources of RS2, there needs to be an examination of the various starches available. 

Test Methods

Resistant Starch Type 2 (RS2) found in raw starches is measured by a method developed by Megazyme, inc., and approved as a worldwide standard in 2002 by the Association of Official Agricultural Chemists (AOAC). The method to test for RS2 is called AOAC 2002.02.

AOAC 2002.02 is performed by numerous US food testing labs. It involves treating the sample with digestive enzymes then freeze-drying and further treating the sample until a final value can be determined. Under AOAC 2002.02, the expected values for several starches are shown below:

  • Raw Potato Starch - 63.39%
  • Hi-Maize Corn Starch - 46.29%
  • Green Banana Flour - 43.56%
  • Corn Flake Cereal - 2.2%

There is not a comprehensive listing of other starches of interest, though a review of journal articles uncover high RS properties of tapioca, arrowroot, sweet potato, kuzu, mung bean, and sago starches.

In some cases, it may be possible to get a "spec sheet" that's supplied by the manufacturer of the starch. These spec sheets list sulfur dioxide, iron, heavy metals, and microbes.  See a sample spec sheet here: Potato Starch Spec Sheet.

Funding

My goal is to raise $20,000 so that I can run triplicate tests on HAMS, RPS, GBF and select tests on tapioca, arrowroot, sweet potato, kuzu, mung bean, and sago starches. I have turned to crowd-funding to avoid any influence by industry. All funds raised will go towards testing, "perks," and fees. If less than the full amount is raised, I will perform single tests on fewer starches.

Each test costs roughly $200, including purchasing, shipping, testing, perks, and Indiegogo's 5% commission. The full funding amount will allow over 100 individual tests. If I raise less than the full amount, I will use it to test what I can. For instance, if I raise just $200, my only test will be raw potato starch. If I raise $2000, I will be able to order 10 tests, etc.

About me

I am the author of The Potato Hack: Weight Loss Simplified and host of the Vegetable Pharm and Potato Hack Chronicle blogs. I have a master's degree in biotechnology and work in the healthcare industry as an electrical supervisor.

My interest in resistant starch began in 2011 after exploring the health benefits of an all-potato diet. I surmised that most of the health effects were due to the RS found in potatoes. I began supplementing with RPS and saw immediate health improvements. I took this idea viral with the help of blogger Richard Nikoley at his Free the Animal blog.  Our discussions on RS led to a worldwide awareness of the importance of RS supplementation.

Please donate!

Thanks,

Tim Steele

Getting RS from whole foods is difficult. Resistant starch is found abundantly in in potatoes, beans, and green bananas, but most of the RS is destroyed in the cooking process, so these foods need to be consumed raw. Research indicates that we need 10-40 grams of RS daily to reap the benefits...equivalent to the RS found in 2 green bananas or a small, raw potato.Dietary sources of RS, ie. cooked potatoes and  beans, supply only 3-5 grams of RS at best. However, raw starches as found in the cooking aisle of any supermarket may be used as an RS supplement. One tablespoon of potato starch contains about 7 grams of RS. Green Banana Flour contains about 5 grams. The problem with using these starches as a dietary supplement is that they have not been tested for RS contents and different starch extraction processes may destroy the RS. Besides potatoes and bananas, a plethora of common starches are available that may also contain RS. Arrowroot, green banana, tapioca, sweet potato, mung bean, kuzu root, and sago palm are all also shown to be high in RS.Types of Resistant StarchRS has been classified into five general types named RS1–RS5, but this project is only concerned with type 2 (RS2). This is the RS found in raw starches and suitable for use as a dietary supplement.Under a microscope, RS2 looks like this:RS2 is in raw starch granules, sometimes called “native starch.” These starch granules are protected from digestion by the structure and composition of the starch granule itself. The structure of the starch granules have an impact on the resistance of the starch. Their compact nature prevents digestive enzymes and stomach acids from attacking the starch allowing it to reach the large intestine whole.  RS2 is found in potatoes, green bananas, plantains, taro, cassava, and in most cereal grains. Not all raw starch is resistant starch. Corn, wheat, and rice starch, for instance are readily digestible for the most part.Boring stuff, right?  Well, read on!Effects of RSHundreds of studies have been conducted over the last 30 years on the effects of RS to:
Improve bowel health
Correct the pH of the Intestines
Increase the thickness of the bowel wall (a good thing!)
Kill cancer cells
Lower postprandial glycemia
Increase insulin sensitivity
Reduce body weight and prevent weight regain
Decrease inflammation in the intestines and entire body
Reduce risk of breast cancer and colorectal cancer
Reduce cholesterol/triglycerides
Increase production of brain neurotransmitters serotonin and melatonin
Remove certain pathogens from small intestine
Preserve Vitamin D in the body
Increase mineral and vitamin production and uptake
Remove toxins and heavy metals from the bloodstream
Increase satiety and regulate hunger hormones
Reduce fat storage after meals

Improve the gut microbiome (synergy, prebiotic, symbiotic)
Protect probiotic bacteria
There are currently about 40 clinical trials registered with ClinicalTrials.gov examining the effects of resistant starch, most using RS2. Nearly all researchers use potato starch or Hi-Maize corn starch, simply because they are unaware of other suitable sources.The Need for AnalysisWith all of these studied health benefits, the only people able to supply us with RS are food manufacturers who can put RS into our biscuits, spaghetti, and bread. There are a few RS supplements being sold as dietary aids, but they do not list the RS content of the product, only the source. I have spoken directly with the makers of most products sold as RS supplements, and most have indicated that they do not test their products. This analysis will be of great help to the manufacturers of RS products to more accurately label and recommend a dosage. It will also steer them away from starches that contain low amounts of RS. What I'm Looking For...I'm hoping to develop a database of the RS2 contents in various starches. At the present time, no one has any idea what the true RS value of a random raw starch is, and few are willing to spend $200 to test. If we discover that most starches tested are nowhere near their hypothetical values in RS, then we can say that using raw starches is not appropriate for supplementation.  Perhaps we will find differences between manufacturers.  If this is the case, then we will be aware that more testing is required to ensure batch consistency.However, we may also find that all samples of certain starches are high in RS and have no issues with safety and quality. In this case, consumers and researchers will have confidence in choosing off-the-shelf raw starches for their supplementation and experimental needs.ConclusionThis project is the first ever to test multiple batches and various types of food-grade starch thought to be high in resistant starch. I will make the most of every dollar to ensure we get the most complete and useful tests.Thank you for backing my project. This is good science, done completely outside the influence of food manufacturers.For researchers and those familiar with RSResistant starch type 2 (RS2) contents of food-grade starches.High Amylose Maize Starch (Hi-Maize), raw potato starch (RPS), and green banana flour (GBF) are universally accepted as excellent sources of RS2. Supplement manufacturers now put these three starches into consumer products and label them as resistant starch. Many doctors recommend supplementing with these starches to increase prebiotic fiber in the diet. However, manufacturers are not required to test and label these products with their RS content, and only Hi-Maize is produced with RS in mind. Manufacturing processes could destroy the RS2 if heat is applied during extraction. This represents a huge problem and could explain the variable individual responses seen in many RS2 studies. My goal is to categorize the amount of RS2 found in off-the-shelf food-grade starches from around the world and explore the RS2 content of other food-grade starches known to be high in RS2 (ie. tapioca, arrowroot, sweet potato, kuzu, mung bean, and sago). When complete, we will have a complete picture of the RS2 content in the most commonly used RS2 sources and possibly discover some others. If enough money is generated, and enough tests can be completed, the results of this project will be written up for publication to aid future researchers, supplement manufacturers, and health practitioners.BackgroundDespite 30 years of research into RS health benefits, there are no supplements available that have been tested and labeled with their RS content. Though food manufacturers have developed several types of RS to act as a functional ingredient in processed foods (RS4 and RS5), it's type two RS (RS2) that is used in most studies, clinical trials, and as supplements. RS2 is a natural, unmodified ingredient that resonates well with people wishing to use an all-natural fiber supplement. The nature of RS2 can change drastically with the addition of heat, and many starches are extracted with processes that require heat. For instance, potatoes are blasted with hot water or steam to remove the peels, and green bananas may be cooked to enable easier peeling. HAMS, sold as Hi-Maize, is a very stable product, yet it also is not labeled with its RS content when sold as a cooking item or consumer supplement. The RS2 in potatoes and green bananas is different among cultivars and ripeness, further complicating matters. Consumers and researchers wishing to use these three RS2 sources rely on faith that their particular batch is a good source of RS2. Hi-Maize is the only RS2 source specifically manufactured to contain a significant amount of RS2.Health ClaimsWith the FDA's 2016 allowance of RS health claims on food labels, more emphasis will be placed on sources of RS in the diet. My intent is to create a resource that can be used by nutritionists, researchers, supplement manufacturers, and people wishing to increase their RS intake. At present, the FDA's claim is only applicable to foods containing Hi-Maize. If this ruling is to be extended to other natural sources of RS2, there needs to be an examination of the various starches available. Test MethodsResistant Starch Type 2 (RS2) found in raw starches is measured by a method developed by Megazyme, inc., and approved as a worldwide standard in 2002 by the Association of Official Agricultural Chemists (AOAC). The method to test for RS2 is called AOAC 2002.02.AOAC 2002.02 is performed by numerous US food testing labs. It involves treating the sample with digestive enzymes then freeze-drying and further treating the sample until a final value can be determined. Under AOAC 2002.02, the expected values for several starches are shown below:
Raw Potato Starch - 63.39%
Hi-Maize Corn Starch - 46.29%
Green Banana Flour - 43.56%
Corn Flake Cereal - 2.2%
There is not a comprehensive listing of other starches of interest, though a review of journal articles uncover high RS properties of tapioca, arrowroot, sweet potato, kuzu, mung bean, and sago starches.In some cases, it may be possible to get a "spec sheet" that's supplied by the manufacturer of the starch. These spec sheets list sulfur dioxide, iron, heavy metals, and microbes.  See a sample spec sheet here: Potato Starch Spec Sheet.FundingMy goal is to raise $20,000 so that I can run triplicate tests on HAMS, RPS, GBF and select tests on tapioca, arrowroot, sweet potato, kuzu, mung bean, and sago starches. I have turned to crowd-funding to avoid any influence by industry. All funds raised will go towards testing, "perks," and fees. If less than the full amount is raised, I will perform single tests on fewer starches.Each test costs roughly $200, including purchasing, shipping, testing, perks, and Indiegogo's 5% commission. The full funding amount will allow over 100 individual tests. If I raise less than the full amount, I will use it to test what I can. For instance, if I raise just $200, my only test will be raw potato starch. If I raise $2000, I will be able to order 10 tests, etc.About meI am the author of The Potato Hack: Weight Loss Simplified and host of the Vegetable Pharm and Potato Hack Chronicle blogs. I have a master's degree in biotechnology and work in the healthcare industry as an electrical supervisor.My interest in resistant starch began in 2011 after exploring the health benefits of an all-potato diet. I surmised that most of the health effects were due to the RS found in potatoes. I began supplementing with RPS and saw immediate health improvements. I took this idea viral with the help of blogger Richard Nikoley at his Free the Animal blog.  Our discussions on RS led to a worldwide awareness of the importance of RS supplementation.Please donate! Thanks,Tim Steele

story:
Please do NOT stop giving... We created a very small initial goal, every dollar raised will continue to help fund the cause.  

October 1, 2015 saw Category 4 Hurricane Joaquin pummeling southern and central Bahamas with 130 mile per hour winds and torrential rain. Completely destroying Long Island, Rum Cay, Crooked Island, San Salvador and Acklins among others, Bahamas now battles an enormous humanitarian crisis. The losses are immeasurable—houses flooded and people losing everything—the trauma unimaginable.

It is now time for us to rise up and help our brothers and sisters in their darkest time of need. As some Bahamians struggles to get the essentials and rebuild their lives, Rotary Clubs of The Bahamas with members of the Bahamian community join hands to work on ground providing emergency supplies and support to the devastated people. The rapid provision of vital aid is crucial in saving lives. However, this is only a part of Rotary’s larger vision of helping people in central and southern Bahamas rebuild itself. After the initial needs are met, then comes the long, hard road to recovery.


Now is the time people like us must step up and help—not just in the short term but over time.

Please donate today. Every dollar you give provides essential supply, shelter and saves lives.


Rotary Clubs Of The Bahamas

Who Are We?

We are a group of focused business leaders and community minded individuals that seek to put service above self to help those that need us the most. Six Rotary clubs in Nassau, one in Abaco, one in Eleuthera and four in Grand Bahama. Our wider family includes a similar number of Rotaract clubs (members between ages 18 and 30), Interact clubs (high school students) and Early Act clubs (primary school students).

For over 50 years, we have systematically leveraged the support of donors in kind, cash and expertise along with our coordinated efforts to feed, educate, eradicate disease and help elevate our fellow man.  We do this without payment and or benefits to which we believe is the best form of paying it forward and advancing the many community service causes that require our work and attention.

We fund raise through interesting and fun projects such as golf tournaments, fishing tournaments,  support of the ‘Ride For Hope’, we lend and use our famous ‘Hamburger Van’ to provide hamburgers and hot dogs at numerous community service events that we or others put on each year, we ring bells for The Salvation Army, we help Doctors locally and abroad give sight to children that never had vision, we help provide hearing aids for children in order to learn to hear and speak, we provide wheelchairs to the Physically Disabled and challenged, we build playgrounds and physical therapy areas for the mentally challenged.

We are male & female, we are young & old, we are black and white and all colors in between – we are equal opportunity warriors that fight for the needs and rights of those that cannot do so on their own.

You ask who and what we are?…….to that we simply say, we are The Rotary Clubs Of Bahamas.

If you believe in what we do, please introduce yourself to a Rotarian today and join us in this most rewarding work to help our fellow man.

Site hosted by The Rotary Club of East Nassau

story:
It was always my dream since my early childhood to become a nurse. I wish to help the poor people in my country Nepal. Our country has a great need of medical professionals. Most of the people are simple farmers who live in remote areas.

There is a lack of health facilities in most villages. Access to hospitals in the cities is difficult too. A greater part of Nepal has no roads and people have to walk most of a day to get to a road, where there is bus service. Please help me with my dream. For the most young people college education is out of question due to lack of family income.
