A greater part of Nepal has no roads and people have to walk most of a day to get to a road, where there is bus service. Please help me with my dream. For the most young people college education is out of question due to lack of family income.

story:
The mission of this fundraiser page.

I have been living with End-Stage Renal (kidney) Failure for about a year and a half now, having dialysis (blood filtering) treatments three days a week, and am now going through the process of receivng a kidney transplant. I am being partially assisted with the mountain of medical and care-related bills by Medicare, but what medicare doesn't cover is still an enormous financial hurdle. And with the prospect of the actual transplant now looming, the out-of-pocket costs are going to mushroom even further.... As an example, just one of the post-transplant medications that I will have to take, which is NOT covered at all, will cost about $5000 (for a three-month supply). Since this all started, I've been very blessed (and quite humbled), as many friends and aquaintences have asked what they can do to help me with the financial burdens of this. I didn't want to resort to a fundraiser/benefit, unless and until I knew for sure that I needed it.... Well, now that it's crunch-time, and the numbers are becoming much clearer, I most definitely DO need it.

I've put this page together, with a modest goal, to (hopefully) help chip away at the current and empendings expenses of this transplant surgery.... A literal "life saver". I can't tell you how much ANY and EVERY contribution, no matter how big or small, will mean to me. I'm so incredibly grateful for the support, prayers and positive thoughts of so many friends,and even total strangers. And this fundraiser will help to propell me through the final, and most crucial stage of this unexpected adventure.

Please, read further, as I would like to tell you a little more about myself. Again, any help at all, in the way of donations, and/or spreading the word about this fundraiser page to YOUR friends and family will mean the world to me.

THANK YOU in advance, for caring enough to read my story. <3

 

 A little bit about me and music.

My name is Jerry Clayworth. I'm a 46-year-old native Texan, born and raised in the home of the Alamo, San Antonio, Texas. I've had many interests and occupations in my lifetime, but the one constant has always been music.... I grew up watching shows like Hee-Haw and The Grand ole Opry, and listening to my grandparents' classic country records. In junior high and high school, I discovered a love for rock and roll as well. I started going to live shows at 16 (when I got my first car), and after taking pictures at several, I approached a local music paper, and my music "career" began! I learned (and loved) every aspect of the music biz, and subsequently tried my hand at booking/promoting shows. I soon learned how many different bases there were to cover, to properly and successfully put together these events, which spurred me to explore the world(s) of graphic design, media relations, networking, etc.... Now, some 30  years later, I still have my passion for music, and am still doing all I can to, both, bring my fellow music lovers opportunities to see and hear great music and artists, as well as coordinate events that assist musicians and others who might be in need.

Over the years, I've put together and/or participated in literally dozens of benefit events, and, with the indespinsable help of SO MANY fine musicians, venues, and others in the music community, we've combined to do a LOT of great things for some really good people and causes! Music is a powerful thing, in more ways than one!

Of course, like most people, I never thought about myself being the one in a position of need, which, even after my initial diagnosis, I had not considered. But, from the very beginning of this personal health ordeal, I've had so many friends and acquaintences, who have asked what they can do to assist me, and many others who have said "If/when you need me/us, just say the word"..... This in itself, is proof-positive, that my passion for music, and the road I've followed, has made all the difference. I am indeed a lucky man!

 

About my kidney failure.

I was diagnosed with End-Stage Renal Failure in October 2011, and have been on hemo-dialysis now for about a year and a half. Once kidney function has failed to the degree that mine has, there is generally zero chance of the kidneys "bouncing back" to a more functional state. I am now forced to have dialysis treatments three days a week, for 5 hours per treatment, in order to survive. This is a process in which two 14-guage needles are inserted into an artery that has been surgically reformed to allow for greater bloodflow, and as one of those lines is drawing out the blood, and filtering the toxins and excess fluids out of it (via a machine and a dialyser -- basically an artificial kidney), the other line is pumping the clean blood back into my system.

I'm very fortunate to have this option available to me, and I'm blessed with an incredible staff at the University Health System dialysis clinic where I go for treatment, however, hemo-dialysis, for all the good it does, is very hard on the body, and especially on the heart, lungs, etc. Because of the toll that it takes on the body, the typical survival rate after one year on hemo-dialysis is about 85%. After that, it drops exponentially (The 5-year survival rate is about 60%, and so forth).

The only option for a healthier life, free of dialysis and it's side-effects, is a kidney transplant.

Where I stand in the transplant process.

Over the last couple of months, I have gone through the barrage of testing that it takes to be approved for a transplant. I have done a psychological evaluation, physical & stress tests, heart scans, full blood workups, and most recently, a bone marrow biopsy. After passing all of these tests, I am now "listed" in the Texas state transplant database, and approved for the transplant!

In a lot of cases, people in-need of a kidney transplant don't have any choice, but to wait for a deceased donor match to come up as they move up the list, which often entails a 6-8 year wait. And even then, it's a matter of surviving those years on dialysis, and then maintaining a level of health that will qualify them, physically, for the transplant surgery.

Having a living donor will, both, trim years off of the wait time, and greatly increase the recipient's lifespan (assuming that they follow a healthy lifestyle, and take their anti-rejection medications as perscribed).... I am very fortunate, that I have (a) living donor/donors who are in the testing process now, and it appears that, through either a direct match, or a paired donor, I will likely be scheduled for transplant in July or August!

Life after the transplant

As those who know me can attest, I will certainly continue working in the music world, and take every opportunity to assist other in-need, via this wonderful vehicle. But now, I have another set of ambitions, too....

Having learned (first-hand) so much about kidney disease and kidney failure over this last year and a half, knowing and getting-to-know so many amazing people who are in-need of, or have had kidney transplants, I want to do what I can to help and support others in their journey to regain health, as well as to educate more people about kidney transplantation, and becoming living donors. I've now said many times, that if I had ever been asked if I would donate one of my kidneys BEFORE going through this terrible ordeal, my first thought would have been "Whoa! I don't know if I can do THAT".... But, if I had known what I know now, and hadn't faced the actual kidney failure myself, I would donate in a heartbeat!

Post-transplant, I hope to advocate for those going through kidney failure, as well as help to better educate the public on the need for, and process of, becoming a living donor. I've also spoken with my transplant coordinator about putting together guide to assist people in going to the public, via social networking, with their need/search for a kidney donor, and fundraising, to help alleviate the financial burdens, where necessary.

story:
“Character cannot be developed in ease and quiet. Only through experience of trial and suffering can the soul be strengthened, vision cleared, ambition inspired, and success achieved.”  

WHAT

My name is Eric Azbell; I am creating this campaign to raise money for my mother.  My mom was diagnosed with Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma a year and half ago.  This type of cancer in most cases is incurable.  My mother has always wanted to go to Machu Picchu but never could.  I want to raise funds to send her on her dream trip before the cancer limits her ability to be functional.

 

 

WHO

One day I decided to stop into the local library in Lancaster, Ohio unexpectedly to see my mother.  Once arriving to her floor, I caught a glimpse of my mother telling a story to a group of toddlers.  Her voice changed quickly to encompass the many characters in the story.  The children's eyes lit up with each turning page and each new event.   My mother is and will forever be my mother, but she also is the mother of every single child that has ever visited the library.  I remember countless times when a small child would come up to my mom outside of work and greet her with a huge smile.  My mother has raised five children and countless more at her work all without complaining.  She never shows her frustrations, her pain, her anguish, her disbelief, but instead holds hope and faith every day.

 

 

 

HOW

I come to you today for help.  I want to send my mother on her dream vacation.  My mother has always talked about traveling to Machu Picchu, but having to raise five children with little income and with the many growing stacks of medical bills this dream has always been far out of reach.  This is a chance for each one of you to be a part of her story.  My mother could die within a year or live another five years; no one has a clear prognosis other than the she will eventually succumb to the disease. 

Don’t feel obligated at all to donate; if she knew I was writing this she wouldn’t want you to.  But if you are one of those individuals that do feel a strong desire to help out, even in a small way, please do.

Thank you for taking the time to read this fundraising campaign.  Please also, consider sharing with your friends or anyone you know who might want to help.

story:
My name is Csilla Renáta Kiss and I suffer from psoriasis syndrome.

In the last 5 years I have undergone several therapies and have tried different medicines. They had no effect, what’s more, due to the steroid-based therapies my condition has worsened. To top it all I suffer from severe allergy and because of it alternative medicine can not be used.

The only useful therapy was the combined seawater and ligh therapy. During this time my symptoms have disappeared. I should continue this therapy all my life but the social insurance does not cover neither the fee nor the instrument. For me the only solution seeems to be able tu buy the instrument.

I am in despair because I don’t have enough income to finance it. Because of the constant itch and pain I don’t want to meet people and I have to wear such clothing that covers the signs of my disease. I am completely withdrawn from society.

I am aware of the fact that this disease is incurable, however by symptomatic treatment I could re-gain my self-esteem and would be able to socialize again.

I would like to offer 50% of the amount received from donations to a charity established to support treatment of children and adults suffering from this disease. 

Do you know what Psoriasis is?

Psoriasis is an autoimmune disease.

The disease involves the proliferation and hyperactivity of keratin-producing cells of the skin (keratinocytes), which lead to an increased skin cornification. Initially small red patches occur on the skin, which fade if pressed against, and later on these patches start scaling and fall off like dandruff. In addition to the visible symptoms the skin becomes itchy and painful and bleeds.

This is one of the skin conditions that impact most life quality. Patients may find it difficult to develop interpersonal relationships and social affirmation.

Life of patients becomes more expensive due to the costly therapy.

Health Conditions Associated with Psoriasis:

· Psoriatic Arthritis

Up to 30 percent of people with psoriasis also develop psoriatic arthritis, which causes pain, stiffness and swelling in and around the joints and tendons.

· Cardiovascular Disease

· Diabetes

· Depression

It's been said that depression is the no. 1 comorbidity of psoriasis. People with psoriasis are twice as likely to become depressed as the rest of the population.

story:
Hi.

I am a woman, mother of a beautiful 6 yr old daughter, wife of my darling husband, daughter, sister, doula and friend. My roots are in South Africa and in Denmark, and I now live in Sweden.

In July 2013 I heard a message I never imagined I would ever hear. I got the diagnosis cervical cancer. Shock and anxiety overwhelmed me but also a strong determination to get through this! What followed was amazing treatments at a clinic called Arcadia in Germany, which specializes in treating all kinds of cancer. Chemotherapy and radiation treatment proved to be necessary as well at that stage, to stop bleeding. This I received at the local hospital. Once the treatments were over I had a hysterectomy, initially planned for 7th Nov but which was finally done on the 28th of Jan. 

I was convinced I was all over this by now. But the latest tests showed the cancer had metastasized to some lymph nodes. The treatment offered here now is more and harsher chemotherapy. But talking to my wonderful doctors at Arcadia, I really believe there is another way. Rather than weakening my immune system even more, I believe I need to build it up again and support my body as best I can! What I need to do to get through this last hurdle is 4 weeks of treatment at Arcadia clinic in Kassel, Germany. 

This clinic is a a private clinic and not state funded for foreigners. This is why I need your help, in even the smallest way. It would mean the world to me. 

I thank you from the depths of my heart.

What I Need 

The amount I need to raise is 15.000 euro. All funding will go to the cost of treatment I have at Arcadia, Germany. (www.arcadia-cancer-treatment.com) 

These treatments and my time at Arcadia will entail the latest technology in cancer treatment, ranging from hyperthermia treatments every day, heat therapy, medications, some of which include high dose vitamin C and other vitamin infusions, nutrition, alkaline water, mental training, massage therapy and art therapy. 

And a huge dose of love and fun from the highly professional and compassionate people working there! This is just as important in any healing! 

The Impact

The impact this help will have on my life is not measurable. I will be able to live a healthy, eccentric, artistic, poetic, crazy, loving, caring, happy life for many years to come. I have much more to learn and discover in this life and I feel excited about it! I promise to give back in any way I can.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you feel you would like to help but can't donate, it would mean a lot if you would spread the word about my campaign. You can use the Indiegogo share tools. 

Thank you so much!

story:
Summary

Two good friends (Mark and Duncan) have decided to tackle the 40 mile 5 Boro Bike Ride in Manhattan, New York. 

This time last year, there was no way we would have been able to ride this event together - too much puffing and panting from sitting at our desks. Having spent a little while training though, we are now both very grateful for our fitness and health. So we thought while we're pedaling along the FDR, we wanted to do a little something for those affected by lung cancer that, almost certainly, would not be able to enjoy such an event. 

As this is a fun ride that a lot of people are doing for charity, and as lung cancer has affected many people in our lives, we have decided to use this opportunity to help, even if it's a little. We will be donating all money raised through the campaign to UNITING AGAINST LUNG CANCER, an organization dedicated to the researching treatments and cures for this incredibly misunderstood cancer. 


The Event

The largest cycling event in the U.S. is coming to Brooklyn this Sunday. Close to 32,000 riders will travel a 40-mile route spanning all five boroughs, with the longest routes in Brooklyn and Manhattan.

In Brooklyn, cyclists will cross the Pulaski Bridge, weave down through Williamsburg and the Navy Yard, eventually riding the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway to the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. 

The tour promotes cycling in New York and gives riders the chance to ride in many areas normally closed off to bicycle traffic.

For more info on the race: http://www.bikenewyork.org/

Here is the route we'll be taking. It starts in downtown Manhattan:


The Cause

UALC is the lung cancer research organization in the US. They have the potential to make a significant impact on treatment and a cure. Since 2003, they have awarded over $11.5 million to academic investigators, leading to over $55 million in follow-on funding, new researchers entering the field, and scientific progress that is already impacting lung cancer patients. UALC is funding research that makes a difference.

Lung cancer remains severely underfunded and misunderstood by the public. Anyone can get lung cancer, including never-smokers and those who have quit smoking. Across the country, UALC holds events that raise awareness and put a face to lung cancer. 

For more info on them: http://www.unitingagainstlungcancer.org/


Other Ways You Can Help

If you or your family has been affected by lung cancer, please share this campaign with your network. All proceeds we raise through this campaign will go directly to UALC. We are only targeting $1,000 as this is their recommendation for this particular race. 


Thank you all for your support and word-spreading!

story:
Hello all,

The last few days for Rhode Island and all along the east coast can best be summed up as devastating and eye opening. Several million people still several days after the storm still have no electricity and even worse still have not been able to visit their homes in evacuated areas. Homes have been destroyed, biz's have been flooded, lives have been lost, and millions of people need to be reminded now more then ever that there is a light at the end of the tunnel.

The Newport Buzz Team & The Face Show are launching this fundraising campaign and hosting a fundraiser in an effort to call on our community to come together and do our part to give back to all those who lost so much and hopefully give them HOPE.

You can donate to the fundraiser right here on the site and/or at the fundraiser at Newport Blues Cafe on November 11th. Donations must be received on-line by 11/16.

-----------

THE EVENT

November 11th- Hurrican Sandy Relief Fundraiser

  • Location: Newport Blues Cafe
  • Time: STARTING AT 2PM!
  • Details:
    • A few hours of the event will be family friendly!
    • There is not a set donation/admission fee, donate what you can!
    • Silent Auction & Raffles.
    • Entertainment

    • James Montgomery • Mike Walsh • Skinny Millionaires • Abbey Rhode • Honky Tonk Knights • Kevin Sullivan Band • The Bit Players • Joop and Jake • Atlantic Avenue.

 ----------

OUR IMPACT

All contributions on-line and at our November 11th Fundraiser will benefit the following orginizations that are working hard to get those touched by Hurricane Sandy back on their feet:

50% of proceeds will support Rhode Island Relief Efforts

50% of proceeds will help the Relief Efforts in NY, NJ, and other states.

  • American Red Cross
    • All donations will provide shelter, food, emotional support and other assistance to those affected by the storm.
  • Rhode Island Food Bank
    • Many people in Rhode Island lost their food due to no electricity and from flooding. Many people don't have the means to properly feed their family or themselves. The Rhode Island Food Bank provides food for whoever is in need.
    • Feeding America
    • Feeding America is providing food, water and other supplies to those affected by Hurricane Sandy.
    Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

11/11- Items /services needed for silent auction: Please conatct us if you can donate something to our raffle or silent auction. Everything welcome.

PLEASE consider sharing this page with EVERYONE you know. 

Thank you for taking the time to read this and support this relief fundraiser. As a community we feel confident that we can stand up and help our fellow Rhode Islanders and neighbors bounce back from this.

Special thank you to Newport Blues Cafe for hosting this event!

 

Sincerely, 

Christian, Ryan, Tristan, and Tim

"In every community, there is work to be done. In every nation, there are wounds to heal. In every heart, there is the power to do it." -Marianne Williamson

story:
Here's Our Story:

What do you get when you take a group of four strangers, mix them with an intentionally diminutive vehicle, and a car rally that stretches 10,000 miles from London, England to Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia? 
An epic adventure called: The Mongol Rally!

We’re Mike, Lauren, Erin, and Brandon, and we’ve teamed up as the Mongolistic 4 to participate in the event that is touted as "the greatest adventure in the world." But, it would be selfish for us to have all the fun, so we want you to come along with us on our journey!

Not only is the Rally about adventure, seeing the world, and making new friends, but a large part of it deals with raising money for charity, Cool Earth and Charity Water to be more specific, and we’re working hard to raise money to make this happen. 
Mike has put us all on a strict budget, Erin and Lauren are organizing car washes, and Brandon, a former opera singer, is putting his lungs into overdrive to raise the minimum funds. Still, even with all these efforts, we’re going to need your help.

What We Need & What You Get

The good news is that we’ve plunked down the cash for our trusty car. Hopefully, our 2001 Mazda Demio (that's a picture of Mike in the boot) is going to get us to Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. Still, we’re missing one key element: Petrol

By fueling our car, you're helping us fund our adventure, and in turn, you’ll be able to feel as though you’re on the Rally with us. 

How? 

By donating just $25, we’ll send you a postcard from wherever we happen to fill up along the route to Mongolia. 

It's Simple

With our expected route, we’ve estimated that we’ll need approximately $1,600. This includes any missed turns or unexpected detours(the scenic route). 
But, we’re doing all the dirty work, so you can sit back and watch how disheveled our car becomes after 10,000 miles through dirt, sand, and tarmac.

Act Fast!

  • The amount of donations and time frame for this campaign are limited.
  • Spots are limited to first 64 people.
  • By acting fast, you’ll be guaranteed a postcard from a country in Europe or Central Asia, and we’re betting that none of your family or friends will have anything like it.

Other Ways You Can Help

Don’t have $25 to drop on our adventure? 

No problem! 

You can still help us out while following us throughout our journey across Europe and Central Asia. Here’s how:

  • Follow us on Twitter @mongolistic4
  • Like us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/MongolisticFour

And that’s how we roll.

Thanks a million!

The Mongolistic 4

story:
The Yoga Boat is going to offer yoga in a slightly new way. With a large open deck, The Yoga Boat will enable a class with up to 20 students to practice yoga out on the water. This boat will offer FREE YOGA and run solely off of donations to pay the instructors and help save to fund the construction of more yoga boats! Well donations don't make it necessarily free, but, I want as many people as possible to be able to enjoy the life changing experience of yoga out on the water! I don't want The Yoga Boat to run off greed and focus on profits. I want The Yoga Boat to remind people that with love, and the support from the community, we can come together and create something that everyone will benefit from and enjoy. No limbs lost. I've always had a passion for the water and helping people. I bought my first small pontoon summer 2012 and if I wasn't in school or at work, I had my pontoon loaded with friends and was at the lake. Being out on the water helps me clear my mind and relax. It's also a great physical therapy for me, being that I have a hip condition. With yoga, I feel the water is the perfect environment to practice in. This will be my first step into yoga and I plan to document everything with hopes to put a documentary together to display all the wonderful benefits of yoga. From a spiritual standpoint, to helping me with my hip limitations, I want to help show the world that yoga can be a strong practice to utilize in our everyday life. Imagine a cool spring sunrise out on the water and you're in your mellow morning class getting ready to ease into the day. Or, you're looking for that jump-start for your mind and body and you're in your power yoga class. Either way, nature offers some of life's greatest experiences and is something we need to survive and live a life of true happiness.

Euphoria awaits! Art by: Nate Sanchez

The first pieces of steel laid out

The barrels I'll be using for buoyancy

Sealing the steel for protection

Installing flooring. Finished flooring will depend on how much is brought in through Indiegogo

Well, about half way through, due to some unforeseen events, I hit a financial wall. It stopped construction and I've been on a bumpy path ever since. I've also had to relocate my entire construction site due to the change in property management at the property I began construction at.

So I packed up and left!

The pictures displayed show half the boat. I'm building another identical section which will connect to this one. This will make the deck 16 feet wide, by 24 feet wide. That's 384 sq. ft. I've made it into two section so I can trailer it down the highway. 

With your support, I'll get the needed materials (electric motor, flooring material, canopy materials, lighting etc.) to finish the boat. You'll be able to see where your money is going via Facebook. 

Perks!

Thank you!

Thank you for your time and support. I believe my purpose in life is to help others. This is my first step into helping others on a larger scale and I can't wait to get it out on the water.

Namaste~

http://www.facebook.com/TheYogaBoat

Hey, just want to let you know that if you click on the links above, they'll take you to The Yoga Boat weekly update videos. Start from the first picture and work your way down. Enjoy!
story_txt:
The Yoga Boat is going to offer yoga in a slightly new way. With a large open deck, The Yoga Boat will enable a class with up to 20 students to practice yoga out on the water. This boat will offer FREE YOGA and run solely off of donations to pay the instructors and help save to fund the construction of more yoga boats! Well donations don't make it necessarily free, but, I want as many people as possible to be able to enjoy the life changing experience of yoga out on the water! I don't want The Yoga Boat to run off greed and focus on profits. I want The Yoga Boat to remind people that with love, and the support from the community, we can come together and create something that everyone will benefit from and enjoy. No limbs lost. 

I've always had a passion for the water and helping people. I bought my first small pontoon summer 2012 and if I wasn't in school or at work, I had my pontoon loaded with friends and was at the lake. Being out on the water helps me clear my mind and relax. It's also a great physical therapy for me, being that I have a hip condition. With yoga, I feel the water is the perfect environment to practice in. This will be my first step into yoga and I plan to document everything with hopes to put a documentary together to display all the wonderful benefits of yoga. From a spiritual standpoint, to helping me with my hip limitations, I want to help show the world that yoga can be a strong practice to utilize in our everyday life. 

Imagine a cool spring sunrise out on the water and you're in your mellow morning class getting ready to ease into the day. Or, you're looking for that jump-start for your mind and body and you're in your power yoga class. Either way, nature offers some of life's greatest experiences and is something we need to survive and live a life of true happiness.

Euphoria awaits!      Art by: Nate Sanchez


The first pieces of steel laid out

The barrels I'll be using for buoyancy

Sealing the steel for protection

Installing flooring. Finished flooring will depend on how much is brought in through IndiegogoWell, about half way through, due to some unforeseen events, I hit a financial wall. It stopped construction and I've been on a bumpy path ever since. I've also had to relocate my entire construction site due to the change in property management at the property I began construction at.

So I packed up and left!
The pictures displayed show half the boat. I'm building another identical section which will connect to this one. This will make the deck 16 feet wide, by 24 feet wide. That's 384 sq. ft. I've made it into two section so I can trailer it down the highway. 
With your support, I'll get the needed materials (electric motor, flooring material, canopy materials, lighting etc.) to finish the boat. You'll be able to see where your money is going via Facebook. 


Perks!


Thank you!Thank you for your time and support. I believe my purpose in life is to help others. This is my first step into helping others on a larger scale and I can't wait to get it out on the water.
Namaste~
http://www.facebook.com/TheYogaBoatHey, just want to let you know that if you click on the links above, they'll take you to The Yoga Boat weekly update videos. Start from the first picture and work your way down. Enjoy!

story:
"I NEED a cup of hot tea and the 'brick'."

Years ago, my girlfriend from college would have extremely painful periods; so painful that she would be wrapped up in a fetal position on the futon clinging to her chamomile tea. 

The best way to cope with the pain was a brick that we found out in the backyard. I would "nuke" it (heat it in the microwave),  she would lay it on her stomach and fall asleep as it worked its wonders. 

Since then, my significant others would add "a brick" to their monthly recipe. Granted this was after a raised eyebrow and a "You want me to do what?" expression when I first suggested it.

However, there were problems

  • Bricks are dirty
  • Bricks are pointy
  • If you wrap a hot brick in towel, it can fall out and you can get burned
  • When you shift your position, see above :(

So, last year my wife and I spend time sculpting and testing a comforting form, trying out different materials and, finally, producing about 50 finished stones :)

Funding will help but what we really also need is ...

proven interest!

Before a major store will carry your product, they want to know if there is enough interest to carry it. I can talk til I am blue in the face but what really speaks louder is numbers. 

  • We would love to be able to say "Hey, 100,000 people gave us a dollar because they said they would like to buy the Sympathy Stone in your store!"
  • We need about $20,000 to create several more batches, get custom sweaters made and packaging.
  1. For a $1, you can help us convince businesses that they should carry our stone
  2. For $10, you can get a code / coupon for $10 off when the Sympathy Stone is available
  3. For $100, we will send a Sympathy Stone to your door (We only have about 50 at this time!)
  4. For $800 (or more), we will send you a Sympathy Stone, ask your input on how we should promote and market our product and send you a years worth of tea!

If we don't reach our goal -> we will still put the funds towards getting this product into stores because we really believe in it -> as well as those who have tried it!

Simple and Pure 

While there is no doubt to the benefit of modern medicines, sometimes the best remedy is prevention. Likewise, sometimes you don't want to ingest a chemical to provide relief (although my wife tells me the Motrin is close to the tea!) 

The Sympathy Stone offers relief and comfort in a pure and simple way:

  • Just put in in your microwave for 2 minutes
  • Grab the headed stone but the provided "handle" 
  • Place on your belly or wherever it will soothe the most
  • Relax

We have found that heating it for about two minutes will let the stone provide close to two hours of warmth and comfort.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to our project:

  • Share our page with your friends and family and maybe tweet about it.
  • There are allot of tools that this site has for you to use to share

Thanks so much for reading all of this. We really appreciate your time and contribution.

This has been a thought for years and, with ALOT cajoling from my amazing wife, we are giving it a shot. If we can provide some comfort, then it is more than worth the efforts.

Take care and be safe :)

story:
Our Story

I met the love of my life on June 16th, 2006 and we were married May 1st 2010. We have one daughter who is 3 years old. After two long hard years of trying on our own to conceive we were diagnosed with Infertility.  I have multiple cysts on both ovaries that make it impossible to ovulate. Diagnosing it was simple as we already knew something wasn't right.. Accepting the diagnosis and treatments available wasn't as easy. After the diagnosis I underwent every possible test under the sun to see what our options were to be able to have just one more child... as it turns out without IVF we have less than a five percent chance of having any other children. To write that is almost as hard as asking complete strangers for help... but without doing this and reaching out we may never have a chance at welcoming another life.

The Impact

The diagnosis for me was devastating. It goes against ever fiber in me to not be able to carry my husbands child.. to know that our chances are so minuscule without intervention is unbearable at times. To think that every time my daughter asks why she doesn't have a baby brother or sister like her friends is heartbreaking.Every month welcomes new hope and every month it is taken away from me. I have been through countless tests including ultrasounds, Hysteroscopy's, Hysterosalpingogram's, and mock IUI's, all paid out of pocket due to my insurance not covering anything to do with infertility. Without your help it will be impossible to raise the funds needed for the medications along with the procedure.


What We Need & What You Get

All donations would go towards our costs for IVF. 

1 Cycle IVF- 7,800
ICSI           - 1,525
Meds         - 3,700

I know it is a lot to ask of people to donate during these hard economic times, and I wish there was another way I could raise funds. Thanks in advance for reading our story!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this with anyone you might know willing to help us make our dream come true!

story:
Hi my name is Maribeth Clemens and I need your help. My husband Bret’s best friend Jennie and her husband Bobby were involved in a horrible motorcycle vs. truck accident.

The Accident.

On March 17th, 2013 Jennie and Bobby Shadowens were out on a motorcycle ride on one of their first rides of this season when they were hit head on by a pickup truck.  The truck had crossed the center line.  They had just gone through a license check and were only riding at about 30 mph when the truck appeared.  The pickup, driven by an older man, veered out of his lane in a turn in the road and crashed into my friends.  Jennie was thrown from her bike and landed face down with a shattered helmet and Bobbie’s bike ended up landing on top of him.  They both sustained life threatening injuries and were air lifted to Charlotte Medical Center.  They were immediately placed into the Intensive Care Unit where Jennie stayed for three days and Bobby stayed for one week. 

The Injuries and Surgeries.

We learned that Jennie had sustained a right side punctured lung, broken right ankle, and that her left knee and thigh had sustained some pretty bad injuries.  She also suffered broken facial bones and a large slice above her left eye, a broken left hand and various bruising and cuts.   She had a chest tube put in to drain the blood from her collapsed lung, multiple stitches above her eyebrow, Cat Scans, MRI’s, and X-rays.  Her surgeries so far total 3 with more due out in the future.

Bobby did not fare as well.  When he was hit, the bike landed on top of him.  His injuries were an aortic aneurism, an avulsed nerve in his shoulder and two compound fractures, one in his left arm and one in his lower left leg.  The doctors had to put a titanium rod that extends from his left knee to his ankle in order to correct the compound fracture.  He has already undergone several surgeries to his aorta and left arm which also had to have pins put in surgically and is due for future surgeries and skin grafts.  Bobby has also had Cat Scans, MRI’s, and X-rays. 

The Long Road Ahead: Rehabilitation.

When Jennie is released from the hospital, she will have to be admitted to a rehab center to undergo physical therapy.  She is non-weight bearing for three months.  She cannot walk or put any pressure on her legs. 

Bobby will also be placed in a Rehab Facility when he is released from the hospital.  The doctors say he may never have full usage of his left arm due to the severe nerve damage. 

Bobby’s lively hood…using his hands to service and work on motorcylcles.

Please Donate.

Throughout this cycle of events, Jennie and Bobby’s spirits have been surprisingly high.  Never once were the words uttered…how could this have happened to us…?  Instead, everyday we hear them say they are doing great and that they are thankful for their network of friends and family.  Day in and day out people stream in and out of their hospital rooms to wish them well and bring them news or to just sit and watch tv together.  

This is why I have started this cycle of giving.  I know the motorist that hit them does not have enough insurance to cover the enormous amount of medical bills my friends will incur.   Although I have set a limit of $20,000, Jennie and Bobby will need so much more.

I also ask that everyone who reads this please pass the word on to others.   Jennie and Bobby will need all the help they can get on their long road to healing.  I know that Jennie and Bobby will be grateful for your support.  Just a FYI, 100% of all funds will go directly to Jennie and Bobby.

story:
....It's Zombie Time...

My name is Jessica and I am an avid runner. Running helps calm me and bring me peace, it also controls my temper as I let my emotions bottle up inside. When I run I feel free and alive, I feel I stomp out my anxieties and internalized stressors- it's my only real rapture- it keeps me going & stay positive. My job is currently a Renal Dietitian & I have transfered job sites to Los Angeles to follow family and be in a more positive environment from the cold East Coast. Upon my very quick move, (I thought I'd have more time to move & prepare) I was forced to back down from my one very exciting (and already paid for) goal of running the Ragnar Relay Race in May 2013 in Cape Cod- a race our team has prepared for- for over a year. We are an amateur zombie themed team infecting all of the East Coast- we raise extra funds each race for outside chairties and we infect others with our one thing we all share- our love for zombies! 

By funding my goal to raise funds to fly to the East Coast I will be able to support myself and my team in running together one more time. This companionship and team effort keeps me going and is the motivation I need to continue to run. I love my team and I want to be a part of this with them. I plan to fly back- average flights are from 500-600$. The rest will be used for transport and if any is left over- I assume it will, I will donate it to the wounded warrior project- our charity that we also raise funds for.

What I Need & What You Get

By funding my goal to raise funds to fly to the East Coast I will be able to support myself and my team in running together one more time. This companionship and team effort keeps me going and is the motivation I need to continue to run- running makes me a better person. I love my team and I want to be a part of this with them.

What the funds are going towards: 600$ for flights, 100-150$ transport to and from airplane/rental car. If I can get a cheaper flight, the rest of the money will go to our chosen charity for this race.

Did I tell you I am a Dietitian & a Certified Health Education Specialist? I have previously worked for different weight loss, dialysis, thyroid disorders & diabetes clinics & can tailor a diet/health plan/calorie meal plan to fit your needs- whether you are an athlete, fitness person, health conditions or just want to get a bit healthier! I can skype if needed!

What you Get:

5$-49$: I am a clown and will send you pictures of our zombie team running in our full out zombie gear. We will also send you our spray painted zombie stamped signature.

50-74$: We will send you our zombie headbands and a picture!

75$-100$: Did I say I am a Dietitian, do you need some helpful tips to lose weight & become zombified with our zombie stamped signature? Let me know what you need to know about nutrition and I can help! 

101$+: Did I say I am a Dietitian, do you need a basic-calorie meal plan? Let me know your favorite foods from each food group, your height, weight,, age and average physical activity and what that activity is. Do you want to lose weight or just get more fit? I can help!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to help, would you atleast spread the word about my campaign? Shout it out on facebook, twitter and while you are at it check out our team at: http://runningdeadteam.com

Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
First of all, thanks. We know there are so many valuable causes to consider. We appreciate you taking your time to consider Emily’s. If your heart leads you to give, please do. Even a dollar is not too little. If she misses this chance, we're unsure when the next one may come.

(IMPORTANT: To give $1 or ANY amount, click on the "CONTRIBUTE NOW" button.
Then choose, "No Perk, just a contribution." THANKS!!)

Dear friend,

Emily is an incredibly vibrant, funny, and creative young lady who suffers from an illness that causes her to faint unexpectedly (among other symptoms noted in the video above). Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) is a form of dysautonomia -- or the abnormal functioning of the Autonomic Nervous System (ANS).

Instead of sulking, Emily has met this head-on with the belief that she's been "allowed" to go through, in order to help others. With that in mind, in 2011 she created the video above. This video has lead to many people being properly diagnosed and treated. But, today, she needs your help.

On Wednesday, September 5, Emily was matched with a cardiac-alert dog that can help her to stop fainting (details below). Her training begins on October 13, which while extremely exciting, couldn't come at a worst time financially (as many of you have experienced). 

Without the funds required for the expenses related to the 23 days of training, Emily will forfeit her cardiac-alert dog and we're unsure when and if another match will become available.

To that end, we have provided a lot of information on this page to help answer nearly any question you may have in order to feel comfortable in giving.

Emily sees this cardiac-alert dog, "Sunny" as an opportunity for her to create greater awareness of her illness, leading to many more people being properly diagnosed and treated.

We remember very clearly how scary it was for the four years prior to our learning why our daughter was fainting daily. With your help, Emily and we can work together to ensure that no parent, or child has to experience this.

Thank you so much, for your consideration of our daughter.

Bill and Barb

 

----------------------------------- More details below -----------------------------------

 

Imagine for a moment...

Imagine having to live every day knowing that you could faint at any moment. It could happen as you were doing everyday things such as:

  • walking up or down stairs
  • sitting at your desk
  • showering, or taking a bath
  • sitting in a movie theater
  • on a walk with a friend, and more...

For our daughter Emily, this has been her reality since she was 11 years old (she’s now 17). Each year it has gotten progressively worse. Because of this, she needs someone to be with her at all times. 

 

A person can't keep Emily from fainting...but, a dog can.

We were amazed to learn of specially trained cardiac-alert dogs that can actually predict when a person will faint. Even more, they can “tell” the person minutes before (and in some cases an hour or more). This gives the person time to rest and/or notify friends/family or those near them, about what could happen.

 

The $7,750 is for hotel, food, and other training-related expenses for 23 days

Last week, Emily was matched with cardiac-alert dog "Sundance" (or, "Sunny"). But, she needs to be able to attend training on October 13, for 23 days and complete it, before she can take Sunny home.  

 

More than just fainting...

While fainting is the primary reason for Sunny, there are a host of other symptoms that Sunny can assist Emily with, such as:

  • balance, when she's dizzy
  • getting things she needs when she can't get out of bed
  • alerting others
  • and more covered in the video (above)

These cardiac-alert dogs provide people that have been restricted to having nearly no life, to be able to begin to experience a bit of independence and freedom in their lives.

In Emily’s case, her match Sunny will allow her to do things that most of us take for granted:

  • being able to take a short walk alone near home
  • be present at high school (it's her Senior year)
  • go out with friends to a movie or the mall
  • look forward to attending college
  • look forward to getting a job
  • and so much more... 

 

How Long Do Most Matches For Cardiac-Alert Dogs Take?

Most matches take years. Then, typically there are up to five months prior to training in order to raise funds. This match has come unusually fast. Meaning, as thrilled as we are, we only have days to raise the needed funds. 

 

The Timeline

  • September 5: We learned about Emily’s match with Sundance “Sunny.”
  • September 18: When plugging the October 9 date, Indiegogo provided 9/18 for the deadline. This is due to Indiegogo taking up to 14 days to provide funds after the deadline.
  • October 9: the date Emily will need to have the funds in hand by to confirm the hotel, etc.
  • October 13: training begins

Please know that we’re absolutely thrilled to hear the news of this match. It was such fortunate timing for the match. But, unfortunate timing for the funds.

 

About Emily’s Video

Emily’s video (above) was created by her and a friend, just about a year ago. She was 16. Emily did this to help bring awareness to her illness. She wanted the kids at school to have an understanding of why she was fainting and not just be known as the “fainting girl.” 

Since that time, we’ve been told that her video has helped several people to see similarities to themselves (and friends) who have since been properly diagnosed and are receiving treatment. 

This year, Emily has been unable to return to school for her Senior year. She is homebound. Your funds can help change this.

NOTE: The song is by Ingrid Michaelson, "Breakable"  http://www.ingridmichaelson.com

 

How you’ll change Emily’s life (and others)

Two words: Independence; Awareness.

  • Independence: By pre-alerting Emily prior to a syncope episode, her service dog, Sundance (“Sunny”) will allow Emily to have independence for the first time in four years.
  • Awareness: Emily is excited because she believes that Sunny will help to attract people to her as she’s out and about. She believes this will allow her to create even more awareness about her illness, so that more people can be properly diagnosed and helped.

 

Emily’s Story

Looking at Emily, she appears just like any other active, healthy kid. And she was, until six years ago. When Emily turned 11 she began to faint, some times several times a day, and this changed her life in many ways: 

  • Being shunned: Well meaning kids, thought she was anorexic and decided to teach her tough-love by telling her they wouldn't be friends until she began to eat properly.
  • No interaction with friends: Because of the frequency of her fainting episodes (syncope), and the disruption it caused to the school (they had to clear the classroom when a student fainted, per policy) she had to become "homebound." Meaning, Emily had to stay at home and take classes online. 
  • Rumors: Being homebound further isolated Emily. In addition, it fueled rumors that she was pregnant, on drugs, bulimic, and some even said she was faking it.
  • Limited Dance: Once we confirmed that the syncope episodes didn’t harm her brain or heart, Emily was able to resume dance (she'd been dancing since she was four and loves it). Unfortunately, many times she still couldn’t complete a full routine without fainting. And today, is rarely able to attend classes. 

Over a period of three years we sought the minds of two of the best health systems in the country: 

  • Hershey Medical
  • John’s Hopkins

No one could pinpoint it.

In the meantime, Emily tried to make it through school each day, fighting against the many symptoms of her illness, in addition to fainting (see “What is POTS?” below). 

Finally, we heard about Dr. Blair Grubb at the University of Toledo Medical Center. It took nearly a year to see him. But, when we did, he was able to diagnose Emily in about 15 minutes.

While Dr. Grubb has given Emily hope in the diagnosis, and while we can manage some of the symptoms, fainting at any time, any place is still the most frightening of all. 

Having to begin her Senior year in High School as a homebound student, Sunny couldn’t come at a better time for her. But, unless we can secure the funds required for training expenses, it won’t become a reality. 

We appreciate whatever is on your heart to give. Even a dollar is not too little.

 

What is POTS (Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome)?

Postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS, also postural tachycardia syndrome) is a condition of dysautonomia,[1] to be more specific orthostatic intolerance, in which a change from the supine position to an upright position causes an abnormally large increase in heart rate, called tachycardia. Several studies show a decrease in cerebral blood flow with systolic and diastolic cerebral blood flow (CBF) velocity decreased 44% and 60%, respectively.[2] Patients with POTS have problems maintaining homeostasis when changing position, i.e. moving from one chair to another or reaching above their heads. Many patients also experience symptoms when stationary or even while lying down.

Symptoms present in various degrees of severity depending on the patient. POTS can be severely debilitating. Some patients are unable to attend school or work, and especially severe cases can completely incapacitate the patient.

 

Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postural_orthostat...
story_txt:
First of all, thanks. We know there are so many valuable causes to consider. We appreciate you taking your time to consider Emily’s. If your heart leads you to give, please do. Even a dollar is not too little. If she misses this chance, we're unsure when the next one may come.
(IMPORTANT: To give $1 or ANY amount, click on the "CONTRIBUTE NOW" button.Then choose, "No Perk, just a contribution." THANKS!!)
Dear friend,
Emily is an incredibly vibrant, funny, and creative young lady who suffers from an illness that causes her to faint unexpectedly (among other symptoms noted in the video above). Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) is a form of dysautonomia -- or the abnormal functioning of the Autonomic Nervous System (ANS).
Instead of sulking, Emily has met this head-on with the belief that she's been "allowed" to go through, in order to help others. With that in mind, in 2011 she created the video above. This video has lead to many people being properly diagnosed and treated. But, today, she needs your help.
On Wednesday, September 5, Emily was matched with a cardiac-alert dog that can help her to stop fainting (details below). Her training begins on October 13, which while extremely exciting, couldn't come at a worst time financially (as many of you have experienced). 
Without the funds required for the expenses related to the 23 days of training, Emily will forfeit her cardiac-alert dog and we're unsure when and if another match will become available.
To that end, we have provided a lot of information on this page to help answer nearly any question you may have in order to feel comfortable in giving.
Emily sees this cardiac-alert dog, "Sunny" as an opportunity for her to create greater awareness of her illness, leading to many more people being properly diagnosed and treated.
We remember very clearly how scary it was for the four years prior to our learning why our daughter was fainting daily. With your help, Emily and we can work together to ensure that no parent, or child has to experience this.
Thank you so much, for your consideration of our daughter.
Bill and Barb
 
----------------------------------- More details below -----------------------------------
 
Imagine for a moment...
Imagine having to live every day knowing that you could faint at any moment. It could happen as you were doing everyday things such as:

walking up or down stairs
sitting at your desk
showering, or taking a bath
sitting in a movie theater
on a walk with a friend, and more...

For our daughter Emily, this has been her reality since she was 11 years old (she’s now 17). Each year it has gotten progressively worse. Because of this, she needs someone to be with her at all times. 
 
A person can't keep Emily from fainting...but, a dog can.
We were amazed to learn of specially trained cardiac-alert dogs that can actually predict when a person will faint. Even more, they can “tell” the person minutes before (and in some cases an hour or more). This gives the person time to rest and/or notify friends/family or those near them, about what could happen.
 
The $7,750 is for hotel, food, and other training-related expenses for 23 days
Last week, Emily was matched with cardiac-alert dog "Sundance" (or, "Sunny"). But, she needs to be able to attend training on October 13, for 23 days and complete it, before she can take Sunny home.  
 
More than just fainting...
While fainting is the primary reason for Sunny, there are a host of other symptoms that Sunny can assist Emily with, such as:

balance, when she's dizzy
getting things she needs when she can't get out of bed
alerting others
and more covered in the video (above)


These cardiac-alert dogs provide people that have been restricted to having nearly no life, to be able to begin to experience a bit of independence and freedom in their lives.
In Emily’s case, her match Sunny will allow her to do things that most of us take for granted:

being able to take a short walk alone near home
be present at high school (it's her Senior year)
go out with friends to a movie or the mall
look forward to attending college
look forward to getting a job

and so much more... 

 
How Long Do Most Matches For Cardiac-Alert Dogs Take?
Most matches take years. Then, typically there are up to five months prior to training in order to raise funds. This match has come unusually fast. Meaning, as thrilled as we are, we only have days to raise the needed funds. 
 
The Timeline


September 5: We learned about Emily’s match with Sundance “Sunny.”




September 18: When plugging the October 9 date, Indiegogo provided 9/18 for the deadline. This is due to Indiegogo taking up to 14 days to provide funds after the deadline.




October 9: the date Emily will need to have the funds in hand by to confirm the hotel, etc.




October 13: training begins


Please know that we’re absolutely thrilled to hear the news of this match. It was such fortunate timing for the match. But, unfortunate timing for the funds.
 
About Emily’s Video
Emily’s video (above) was created by her and a friend, just about a year ago. She was 16. Emily did this to help bring awareness to her illness. She wanted the kids at school to have an understanding of why she was fainting and not just be known as the “fainting girl.” 
Since that time, we’ve been told that her video has helped several people to see similarities to themselves (and friends) who have since been properly diagnosed and are receiving treatment. 
This year, Emily has been unable to return to school for her Senior year. She is homebound. Your funds can help change this.
NOTE: The song is by Ingrid Michaelson, "Breakable"  http://www.ingridmichaelson.com

Being shunned: Well meaning kids, thought she was anorexic and decided to teach her tough-love by telling her they wouldn't be friends until she began to eat properly.




No interaction with friends: Because of the frequency of her fainting episodes (syncope), and the disruption it caused to the school (they had to clear the classroom when a student fainted, per policy) she had to become "homebound." Meaning, Emily had to stay at home and take classes online. 




Rumors: Being homebound further isolated Emily. In addition, it fueled rumors that she was pregnant, on drugs, bulimic, and some even said she was faking it.




Limited Dance: Once we confirmed that the syncope episodes didn’t harm her brain or heart, Emily was able to resume dance (she'd been dancing since she was four and loves it). Unfortunately, many times she still couldn’t complete a full routine without fainting. And today, is rarely able to attend classes. 


Over a period of three years we sought the minds of two of the best health systems in the country: 

Hershey Medical
John’s Hopkins

No one could pinpoint it.
In the meantime, Emily tried to make it through school each day, fighting against the many symptoms of her illness, in addition to fainting (see “What is POTS?” below). 
Finally, we heard about Dr. Blair Grubb at the University of Toledo Medical Center. It took nearly a year to see him. But, when we did, he was able to diagnose Emily in about 15 minutes.
While Dr. Grubb has given Emily hope in the diagnosis, and while we can manage some of the symptoms, fainting at any time, any place is still the most frightening of all. 
Having to begin her Senior year in High School as a homebound student, Sunny couldn’t come at a better time for her. But, unless we can secure the funds required for training expenses, it won’t become a reality. 
We appreciate whatever is on your heart to give. Even a dollar is not too little.

Several studies show a decrease in cerebral blood flow with systolic and diastolic cerebral blood flow (CBF) velocity decreased 44% and 60%, respectively.[2] Patients with POTS have problems maintaining homeostasis when changing position, i.e. moving from one chair to another or reaching above their heads. Many patients also experience symptoms when stationary or even while lying down.
Symptoms present in various degrees of severity depending on the patient. POTS can be severely debilitating. Some patients are unable to attend school or work, and especially severe cases can completely incapacitate the patient.

story:
International Overdose Awareness Day is an opportunity to remember the people we have lost to overdose.  It is also a call to action.

Overdose deaths can be prevented if people know how to recognize and respond to an overdose. Naloxone (narcan) is one of the important tools that we have to prevent overdose deaths.  In the past decade, more than 50,000 people have been trained to recognize and respond to an overdose and given naloxone rescue kits resulting in over 10,000 overdose rescues.

However, right now there are some major problems:

  • There is a naloxone shortage, which is contributing to increasing naloxone prices
  • Overdose prevention programs don’t have enough money to buy the huge volume of naloxone that people are requesting to save lives
  • There is no federal funding for naloxone programs and the number of philanthropic organizations that fund programs can be counted on one hand

 

Your donation is TAX DEDUCTIBLE when you donate via the PayPal option! YOU MUST CHOOSE PAYPAL WHEN YOU DONATE IF YOU'D LIKE YOUR DONATION TO BE TAX DEDUCTIBLE.

 

Your donation will go directly to purchasing the naloxone.  The first naloxone distribution program in the country, the Chicago Recovery Alliance (CRA), has provided technical assistance and/or start up support to nearly every existing program in the country. This year, CRA doesn’t have enough funds to purchase the volume of naloxone necessary to meet the demand.  This fundraising campaign is our opportunity to appreciate the breadth of CRA’s work and to ensure that CRA continues to be able to provide the same level of naloxone access as in years past.  We need a lot more than $10,000 to buy all the naloxone we need.  Since this is the first time we have tried to raise money directly from the community and because indiegogo will charge 9% if we don’t actually meet our goal, we chose a figure that is about 20% of the amount necessary.  So, if we surpass this goal, the money will still go directly to purchasing naloxone. To receive a tax deduction, donate via the PayPal option.

 

Other stuff you can do to expand naloxone access & prevent overdose:

 

  • Ask your local public health department about naloxone distribution programs- suggest that they begin one.  This is a website with good information.  If overdose is a problem in your community (which it probably is!) the public health department is the organization that should be addressing it. 
  • Talk with your doctor about prescribing naloxone.  S/he might not be familiar with the practice, but here is a lot of good information for prescribers. Also, the American Medical Association just adopted a policy in favor of community based naloxone distribution pilot projects.
  • Write a Letter to the Editor of your local newspaper about International Overdose Awareness Day, the overdose epidemic and ways to prevent fatal overdoses, such as naloxone distribution programs. 
  • If you have any connections with philanthropic organizations, encourage them to fund overdose prevention programs.  Overdose is the #1 cause of injury related deaths in the country- more than car crashes, drowning, fire arm deaths.

 

Are you scared, frustrated, heartbroken and/or angry?

Consider joining a group for families concerned about overdose like Learn To Cope, Broken No More, Grief Recovery After a Substance Passing (GRASP), all of which have many chapters and forums for support on-line.

 

Want to know more?

We are happy to talk more off line, too!  Leave contact info in the comments section, make your comment private if you don't want others to see your contact info.

Find out about International Overdose Awareness Day events around the globe here

Find the overdose prevention and naloxone distribution program closest to you here

story:
The body cord connects the fencing weapon to the rest of the scoring system (those colored lights, if you've ever watched a tournament).  For YEARS, fencing companies have made few, if any, true improvements to the technology, leading to repeats of the same flaws over and over.  To make matters worse, NEW fencing companies typically copy existing designs...which is cheaper for them (meaning greater profits), but simply perpetuates the flaws...instead of taking a little time to think about how to correct the problems (and as a certified armorer....I've seen a LOT of it).

I've gone through all the major brands and have kept the good features, tossed the bad ones, and added a few touches of my own to create a cord that has proven reliable and long-lasting in use, both on my own armory test cord (which probably gets harder use than fencers give their own gear), and on cords used at the fencing club I work out of.

The design is proven, but what I've always lacked was sufficient funds to properly develop and produce the cord (the same applies to other designs for the sport I've done).  I have a manufacturer ready to start prototyping the latest changes, but I obviously need the funds to start the process!

The design elements could also be adapted for other uses where a plug connection is desired.
